reviewText: Really well done.  Apart from not having read In Cold Blood, the only thing about it that I didn't really know was what Harper Lee was at one point actually quite public.  I always thought she was reclusive.  I thought the tension on Hoffman's part was well done, but I notice that people in review seem to emphasize Capote's need to get his book done as his primary conflict in holding compassion for the killers, but I also felt that he reached a point that he was repulsed by their actions and felt trapped morally, too...

reviewText: 276 Amazon customer reviews as of now for "Capote" and only 61 for "Infamous"... Have you heard of "the other movie"?"Capote" came out in '05 and "Infamous", right behind it, in '06. That's been at the expense of "Infamous" and more importantly of the public- because "Infamous" is the better film. Since it came out a year after the well recieved and highly publicized "Capote" I guess America had enough Capote and had paid enough attention to the somehwhat grim story behind the creation of the novel "In Cold Blood".As far as "Capote" goes it's a good film and deserving of critical praise, especially of coarse for Philip Seymour Hoffman who ended up with an Oscar. He did about as good a job as any actor could in portraying the famous, "eccentric"(lol) author.Hoffman did about as good a job as any could, except for one Toby Jones.Toby Jones is a talented actor and happens to be a Truman Capote look-a-like. It is uncanny, the physical resemblance. And on top of that Jones perfectly captures the voice Gore Vidal described as sounding what a Brussels Sprout would sound like if it could talk. He was as they say, born for part.Of coarse the films must be compared: They both have their strenghts and respective flaws or weaker aspects. But as many have said, they serve as great companion pieces -each offering a different perspective on a complex artist and the events surrounding the creation of his greatest work. What a unique and interesting situation to have two very well made films done at about the same time and on the same fascinating subject.The more entertaining -and at least as well acted film- is "Infamous", however. And after seeing Toby Jones as Truman Capote, Hoffman is just not as impressive.If you see "Capote" definitely don't fail to miss "Infamous". And vice versa."Infamous" -5 Stars.

reviewText: 'Capote' is an absorbing and fascinating ride through the life of Truman Capote.  It does draw a lot from the power of 'In Cold Blood' without being redundant to the classic movie chiller reinactment of a heinous heartland murder of an innocent family.  The film is focused, but it does retain the personal life of Capote.  It isn't a particularly flattering portrayal (although Oscar winner Phillip Seymour Hoffman certainly earned his place here), even though the unvarnished portrait isn't just a hack job--it exposes the man's vulnerabilities as well as his duplicity.  The movie shows a man of compassion with some strong human frailties to boot.  His personality comes through at cocktail parties and through his lifelong friendship with famed author Harper Lee (played with Oscar-nominated prowess by Katherine Keener).  The best scenes are when Capote interviews the killers.  The Capote story and the killer's story are well represented in this very fascinating movie biography.

reviewText: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences may as well just serve up Phillip Seymour Hoffman's Oscar now, for without a doubt, his performance in Capote is the finest of the year. Hoffman becomes so absorbed in playing the famous author, that he's sure to have a lock on the admiration of viewers everywhere, and the gold statuette.He's nothing short of astonishing, and he never overly imitates the well known, and often mocked, speech patterns or mannerisms of the writer Truman Capote, but rather nails his essences without turning to parody. But the film itself is absolutely mesmerizing, a beautiful, subtle, and beguiling tale, of love and art and journalism; it's terrific movie that thoroughly deserves all the accolades.The film begins in the late '50s when Capote, fresh off the success of Breakfast at Tiffany's. He's now become part of the intellectual and artistic elite, a doyen of the salons and private parties of the Upper East Side and secure in his world and reputation as the New Yorker's best and brightest author.One afternoon he reads a short newspaper article in The New York Times about the slaying of a rural Kansas family, the Clutters. Something about the gravity of the murders captivates him, and Capote decides the topic is perfect for The New Yorker magazine, an article in which he will show the effect of such a brutal murder on the inhabitants of a small town.Within days he heads to the community of Holcomb, Kansas in the company of his boyhood chum, Harper Lee, (a fabulous Catherine Keener), soon to write her one and only novel, To Kill a Mockingbird. Lee serves as his enabler, helping Capote ingratiate himself into the close-knit, and somewhat intolerant, community, as he attempts to make contact with the town's law enforcement professionals and, ultimately, the perpetrators of the deed.As the narrow minded law enforcement officials, led by Alvin Dewey (Chris Cooper) reluctantly give Capote information about the crime, the young reporter befriends one of the imprisoned convicts, Perry Smith (Clifton Collins Jr.) in order to extract as much of his personal perspective about the killings as possible.But it's a relationship forged in dishonesty - it's the story and not the lives of the murderers that really compel the author - and whilst there's obviously an attraction there - they're both eccentric outsiders from the wrong side of the tracks - Capote is shown as ultimately more concerned about getting the story, as he does his best to postpone Perry's execution until he can get all the information that he needs. He must find out exactly what happened on that night in 1959, and he does such a good job of manipulating Perry's trust so that Perry believes he has a friend who will fight for his life.Director Bennett Miller, writer Dan Futterman, and most of all actor, Philip Seymour Hoffman capture this process with exquisite accuracy and with the smallest of flourishes. The genius of the film, besides Hoffman's stunning performance, is that it knows exactly how much is enough. It never overplays, lingers or punches up.The dialogue is intelligent; each scene is carefully laid out, with a gorgeously minimalist piano score that heightens the emotional tension between the characters. Meanwhile, the gray ominous sky and the flat, severe landscape of Kansas, the horizon a hundred miles out, lends its own atmosphere to the proceedings.Did Capote eventually fall in love with Perry? Perhaps, but you leave the film with a definite sense that Capote's feelings towards the condemned man were enigmatic at best, he was a man torn between finding the story and his very real concern for the fate of another human being. Capote is presented here, flaws and all, as someone rather despicable, but he was also quite sensitive. The anguish he suffers at the results of his decisions emerges as our only glimpse of his potential redemption.Capote is a stunning film, and a superb drama, as it mines one of man's darkest moral dilemmas - that of gaining and using another's trust for mostly selfish motivations. Much of the complication comes not only from the acknowledgement of guilt by the perpetrator, but also by the genuine feelings of concern and empathy that Capote develops for Perry, and he discovers that can't easily reconcile these feelings with his cold and calculated objective.The supporting players are exceptional, particularly Keener as Harper Lee and also Bruce Greenwood as author, Jack Dunphy, who was also Capote's partner and lover. But, without diminishing the contributions of all Capote's participants, this is really Hoffman's film. He's an absolute delight. Truman Capote was a complicated, competitive and totally driven man, a literary genius who had many demons, and Hoffman conveys all sides of him to perfection, letting you see the man behind the glasses, the effeminate voice, and the pouting often arrogant humor. Mike Leonard October 05.

reviewText: This was a very smartly made movie.  To understand Capote you must understand the man, and as you watch this movie you really understand the many layers of Truman Capote.  An egotist, that struggles with constant hints at homosexuality, as well as an insane genius.The basic plot of of the movie is that after great success from his novel "Breakfast at Tiffany's" he is onto his next great venture.  In 1959 a family was brutally murdered by close range shotgun in a very bloody massacre.  Truman Capote interviews and empathizes one of the murders to see the man under the crime.  In doing so, he creates one of the greatest non-fiction novels to date, "In Cold Blood."  This movie uses great characterization and you really begin to understand what motivates each character in the story.This movie also used a lot of research, even little things like clearing up the rumor that Harper Lee wasn't the true author of "To Kill A Mockingbird" which wasn't even proven false until after the movie was on DVD, and many of his letters and conversations.  I found this movie very enjoyable, and Hoffman's best acted film to date.  It's much different than a lot of other roles he's done.For those who saw many of the other Oscar nominated movies like Munich, Crash, and Brokeback Mountain, I feel it is time for you to also give this movie a shot.  You won't be disappointed.  Even the special features and commentary on the extras are great.Great transfer, great surround sound, and easily navigable menus make this a really enjoyable DVD, as well as a really enjoyable home theatre experience.  This is definately worth purchasing, or at least seeing.

reviewText: Capote starring oscar-winning actor Philip Seymour Hoffman is an ok film that surrounds a true life story. Truman Capote (Hoffman) is a writer, he is resepected in his field, he wrote the book Breakfast at Tiffany's but for his new book, he decides to write about two men who killed a family in Kansas. His book, In Cold Blood made Capote a legend but it also ended his career as a gifted writer, he felt such tremendous guilt about the way he manipulated one of the killers, Perry Smith. Capote becomes depressed, paranoid and eventually drinks himself to death but none of this is shown in the film. I think the film was good but a bit boring at times. But Hoffman's performance is truly captivating, his performance alone is a reason to watch Capote. Take it or leave it.

reviewText: I'll be brief since this motion picture has already rec'd nearly 300 reviews - CAPOTE is an exceptional, somewhat complex, mature film that engages and satiates the viewer on so many levels.The acting here is simply superb. I'm going to lay claim that Hoffman's effort as the lead character is one of the very finest (Top 10 worthy) performances that I have ever witnessed. The awards he garnished are so well-deserved. And Catherine Keener's subtle yet strong portrayal as Harper Lee is flawless, as is the rest of the cast.The film itself is beautifully shot, and the script is likewise excellent. Really, can one truly find any fault with this motion picture? I dare say, not.Back to Hoffman - he dominates the film as much (or more) than another much more famous and identically-named actor (Dustin, whom I also have high regard for) ever could. I cannot emphasize how brilliant this accomplishment is - Hoffman truly brought Truman Capote to life for me.I plan next to order the 'Infamous' DVD and compare it to this film, though I am hesitant to do so until a few weeks have passed. Like 'Rob Roy' which flew under the radar due to the huge splash made by 'Braveheart', I'm hoping that 'Infamous' is another hidden gem.In the meantime, I will admire 'Capote' for the great film that it is - an easy 5 Star rating here.

reviewText: Truman Capote was such a wretched, damaged, and contemptible caricature of a man that lobbing salvos at him seems unsportsmanlike; indeed, despite his abrasive superciliousness he was so pathetic as to engender not disdain but pity.  Ironically, this well-crafted film finds us recoiling in horror as we witness Capote's descent into complete moral oblivion, while the cold blooded killers he exploits appear increasingly like hapless victims of a devious opportunist.  Capote is a very small movie that focuses a laser beam on one specific thing, the relationship between Capote and the killers.  In doing so, it is able to carefully, and leisurely, develop a very nuanced and subtle psychological drama, a drama almost as chilling as the slaughter of four innocents in a desolate Kansas farmhouse.There is a sense in which all writers are vampires, invading the inner lives of others for material.  Under the best of circumstances this process occurs in good faith, with respect for the subjects and their dignity.  What we see here is what it looks like under the worst of circumstances, when there is only bad faith, betrayal, callous narcissism, and an endless succession of lies. Capote makes his deal with the devil and gets his reward, heightened celebrity and a fabulously successful book.  In retrospect, however, his methods cast doubt on the book's credibility, and the price he paid was dear, typewriter silenced, suicide by alcohol.  Not as quick as hanging, but probably more tortured.Many wonderful performances in this picture.  Clifton Collins, Jr. is faultless as Perry Smith, the limited, almost childishly innocent killer Capote has set his sights on.  Catherine Keener's Harper Lee is equally on point, while Bob Balaban is perfectly cast as New Yorker Editor William Shawn.  Which brings us to Philip Seymour Hoffman's celebrated embodiment of Truman Capote, a subject presenting two different problems.  The first is that his recreation is so uncanny one feels one has spent two hours in the presence of Truman Capote, roughly the equivalent of a month in Leavenworth.  The second is the effortless way Hoffman slips into Capote's tiny shoes, almost as if the part had been designed for him.  Indeed, from The Talented Mr. Ripley to Magnolia to Along Came Polly, Hoffman is always exactly the same person; pasty, bloated, debauched, passing for straight, alcoholic, corrupt, and completely devoid of moral fiber.  This is a man who, if he noticed a burning bishop on the other side of the street, would not cross that street to pour his beer on the bishop's head.  So, while the performance may be justifiably admired, I am more inclined to tip my hat to the casting director.

reviewText: Warning:  This review contains a lot of background and contexting!CAPOTE the movie with Phillip Seymour Hoffman is an excellent movie with excellent precedents.  Less than two years after Truman Capote's masterwork, IN COLD BLOOD was published in 1966, a highly-acclaimed film version was released starring Robert Forsythe as the investigator and Robert Blake as Perry Smith the half-Indian, half-Irish "changeling" whose gentle air and violent pathologies so attracted Capote the researcher, more so than Perry's accomplice Dick Hickock.  After IN COLD BLOOD the blockbuster "nonfiction novel" and IN COLD BLOOD the movie, in the eighties came biographer Gerald Clarke's excellent and accessible biography CAPOTE, and it is from the middle third of his book that CAPOTE the movie is largely taken.The three adult Capotes each carve out a distinct niche in American letters, and, thanks to the author's savvy with publicity, represent three different icons. As a young adult Capote's writings were symbolist and somewhat ethereal, epitomized by his first full-length novel, OTHER VOICES OTHER ROOMS. But even the young Capote, anticipating middle-aged Truman's dictum that "a boy has to sell his books" was a risk taker:  his "come-hither" jacket photograph reminded people more of soft-core gay pornography in the staid postwar era than of the corduroy-with-elbow-patch type of author portrait then the norm.The middle Capote, our subject here, was the one who existed between November 15, 1959, the day he read about a rural family slaughtered on the Kansas Plains, and ends only with the killers' execution in 1966 and the publication of IN COLD BLOOD.  The third, and saddest part of the Capote saga is the alcoholic, frequently semi-coherent and malicious sprite of the TV talk shows, antagonizing lifelong friends yet titillating audiences with the remaining flames of his wit and abilities as raconteur.  Our movie here does a sublime job of allowing how that character was created.  IN COLD BLOOD was Capote's triumph but ultimately his tragedy too.As with Clark's biography, the 2005 film CAPOTE shows how the Clutter family murder quickly became Truman's "meat," yet how the painstaking, years-long writing of the book and the even more painstaking wait -- let's be honest -- for the killers to be executed before the book could be released to a grateful American public in 1966.  The film ends with the killers' execution by hanging.First, highest praise for Philip Seymour Hoffman, who has the "tiny terror" and his personality down pat, everything from his boozy, court-holding parties to his immense scrupulousness and fact-checking while researching in Kansas for IN COLD BLOOD with his old buddy (Nell) Harper Lee, she of TO KILL A MOCKINGBIRD.  (Could a Hollywood screenwriter do better than this?)  The Capote he reveals is the Capote at his height, but he shows us how the seeds of Truman's ruin lay in what IN COLD BLOOD took out of him and he could never recover.There was another Capote besides the merry prankster and wit.  Charming Truman could be all bird-dog and utter seriousness when researching his book.  He and Harper Lee moved to Garden City, Kansas, talked to dozens of locals, yet used no tape-recorders nor took notes in front of the interviewees on the theory they would inhibit them from faithful recollection and emotion.  Late each night a note-comparing session was held, while Truman with his self-proclaimed "94 percent recall" trued his quotes and facts with Lee's.**MILD SPOILER GRAF**  Despite some welcome comic relief, CAPOTE, for all its excellence, is no one's idea of a "feel-good movie."  IN COLD BLOOD the "nonfiction novel" could draw on considerable dramatic irony in detailing the world the four Clutter family members were forced to depart.  The late Indian-summer weather after their demise was beautiful, ending in (to use a Capote-ism) an "arid glitter" and leaving local ranchers hoping for an "open-range winter."  The movie on the other hand, lacking I would guess the length to develop such symbolic irony (or unfairly afraid the audience might get confused, or both), opens to leaden skies and stays that way.  While I support dramatic license for the sake of a good taut movie, I personally was disappointed that the Clutter house was portrayed as a prosaic clapboard farmhouse (with Manitoba subbing for Kansas), instead of the self-designed, two-story brick real Clutter house, with its family-owned natural gas well and "intermittent displays of spongy, liver-colored carpet" covering the hard wood of the living room. In IN COLD BLOOD the book, it is made clear the reason the successful, outgoing and unpretentious Clutter family made for the most horrific victims:  "Anybody else, it wouldn't have mattered so much," said the wife of a Japanese farmer, but the Clutters were the local ideal, successful, hardworking, unpretentious and friendly, and very much a part of the placid, if slightly phony, peaceable late Eisenhower ideal.  Except for the character of Alvin Dewey, the crime's lead investigator, and a few New Yorkers, most of Capote's characters detailed in the book are given different names -- after all, most of the contemporaries of the teenage Clutter chldren on the eve of the Sixties are still robust and just entering Senior Citizenship.  Even Perry's surviving sister Fern gets a pseudonym.  At least once, CAPOTE the movie creates a composite character:  churchgoing Nancy Ewalt and friend-of-the family Sue Kidd are rolled into adolescent "Laura Tunney."But what the movie does, and does to perfection, is document Truman Capote's growing fascination with "changeling" Perry Smith.  "I felt we were the same person," Hoffman's Capote confesses at the end of the movie, "except Perry left the house through the back door and I left it through the front."  Also in accord with Clarke's biography, the film makes it clear that Capote was extremely sympathetic to Dick and Perry -- but only up to the point.  After a time he basically needed them dead and slowly withdrew communication with the condemned men.See this film--it is effective and Hoffman's performance is nothing short of extraordinary.  I can forgive the early glosses over the naturalism of IN COLD BLOOD's careful delineation of the Clutter family's life and character; in this movie THEY are the background while Capote's relationship with the prisoners is to the fore.Then, please read IN COLD BLOOD. Despite the fact that in the button-down world of publishing no one knew whether to class the book as fiction or non, it is a tour de force and few people who read it come away unmoved.  Then I would strongly urge the interested to read Clarke's bio of Capote, CAPOTE, still in print.  IN COLD BLOOD the sixties movie is worth a visit, as is HOW BRIEF A TREAT, a selective volume of Capote's letters from the 1940s to the 1980s, edited by Gerald Clarke and emphasizing the IN COLD BLOOD 1960s.  OTHER VOICES, OTHER ROOMS is as powerfully symbolic as it was in 1948, as are Capote's many short stories and holiday reminiscences.  I do hope this concentration of interest forces more of Capote's out-of-print works back into print (the reader may recall that this happened to Patricia Highsmith's *oeuvre* two years ago).  Worth going to some trouble to find in particular is THE MUSES ARE HEARD, a sympathetic but slightly prickly memoir of Capote's 1956 journey to Moscow with the American cast of "Porgy and Bess" on a cultural exchange mission to the U.S.S.R.  Like his other work it is sublimely written and this time sublimely funny too.[...]
summary: An excellent addition to an excellent and growing canon....

reviewText: As the title suggests, this movie concerns the author of the 1966 classic, In Cold Blood, not the horrific quadruple murder in Holcomb, Kansas on November 15, 1959 on which Truman Capote based his greatest work. Viewers who expect a retelling of the book will be disappointed.But this story has great merit on its own, for it perfectly depicts the delicate, difficult (and in this case compromised) balance between a great writer's desperate urge to tell the truth and the strategy he must employ to obtain it. The day after the murders, Capote (Philip Seymour Hoffman) opens the New York Times, reads an account of the murders on the inside pages, carefully and neatly clips the article and calls his New Yorker editor, William Shawn, to say he will change course to write about the crime.Famed for Other Voices, Other Rooms and Breakfast at Tiffany's, the novelist initially plans an article or series, but Capote's work swiftly expands into something much more grand--and dark. He shamelessly declares to his lover, friends and associates, including Harper Lee (Catherine Keener), that this story will let him create a new genre, the non-fiction novel. To some, Capote's pronouncement seems pure braggadocio. Yet remarkably, he fulfills his promise, in a breathtakingly gruesome and insightful account (read by this viewer long ago), again today a bestseller.Highlighted here is Capote's means of investigating what drove Perry Edward Smith (Clifton Collins, Jr.) and Dick Hickock (Mark Pellegrino) to their deeds. For years, he doggedly reports, collecting every available document and interviewing everyone associated with the killers or their victims--rural businessman and farmer Herbert Clutter, his wife Bonnie, his 16-year-old daughter Nancy and his son Kenyon.But only through Capote's own lies and prevarications can he sufficiently engage the perpetrators that they will reveal their motive and the awful details of the Clutters' deaths: spurred by a false rumor that Clutter had $10,000 in his prairie home, Smith and Hickock embarked upon a fruitless search that yielded them only rage, some $40 or $50, buckets of blood--and their own eventual demise on Kansas gallows. (Parents, beware: Flashback scenes make this film highly unsuitable for children.)To gain interviews, access to legal documents and obtain unlimited visitation rights, Capote cozies up to families, friends and colleagues of law enforcement officials and even bribes the warden at Leavenworth, where the killers are soon transferred. He also ingratiates himself with friends and families of victims and killers alike. Armed with photos and details of the killers' broken and dysfunctional early lives, Capote begins conflicted friendships with the two men, both convicted of four counts of first degree murder and sentenced to death.Capote develops seemingly genuine sympathy for the imprisoned murderers. Upon his return to Kansas, Capote learns that Smith has not eaten for a month, races out to buy baby food and then spoon-feeds him. But his kindness is ultimately self-serving, for it also ensures that Smith won't die before telling Capote details of the murders.Fairly early in his investigation, Capote decides to entitle his as-yet-unwritten non-fiction thriller, In Cold Blood.Later, even after completing two thirds of the book, Capote lies to keep Smith talking. Smith reads a news report on Capote's recent New York reading, confronts him, and demands to know the book's title. Without hesitation, the straight-faced Capote says he has no idea. The reading's organizers concocted that title, he lies to Smith, in hopes of sensationalizing the event and drawing a big audience. Smith continues talking to his "amigo."Capote's empathy is not entirely duplicitous. While repulsed by the evil deeds of Smith and Hickock, he finds and funds an attorney to appeal their case.At some level, Capote relates to them: His own childhood was unhappy. Born in New Orleans, Capote was dragged from place to place by his promiscuous mother, who abandoned him before he was sent to relatives in Alabama. Capote can't precisely explain, he tells Harper Lee, his childhood Alabama friend, in his characteristically high, disconcerting voice. "It is as if Perry and I grew up in the same house, and one day he went out the back door and I went out the front." The case has radically changed his life, he says. Yet Capote leverages his sympathy and personal experiences to gain his subjects' confidence.Moreover, when the killers' appeal reaches the Supreme Court years later, Capote wants only to finish his story, which implicitly requires that their lives end. Thus Smith's request for Capote to find another attorney generates a brief reply, in which Capote claims to have exhausted all possibilities. In truth, this time, he has done nothing and no longer wants to.While Harper Lee's masterpiece To Kill a Mockingbird becomes a bestseller and blockbuster movie, she also becomes Capote's alter-ego and his conscience. Only her intervention prompts Capote to rise from his drunken stupor in New York and fly to Kansas with New Yorker editor William Shawn to visit Smith and Hickock one last time. There, Capote confronts his own internal conflict, and at Smith's request, tearfully agrees to witness their executions.There's no secret to the ending of this tale: In Cold Blood made Capote one of America's greatest writers. In the book, he wrote, "Four shotgun blasts that, all told, ended six human lives." But that's false too. In reality, the crime killed seven, including the author who shone world attention on the murders. This movie tells us why, however great, Capote never finished another book, and probably why he drank himself to death.--Alyssa A. Lappen

reviewText: First of all, I am a fan of Philip Seymore Hoffman.  I have long hoped to see more of him and in more challenging roles.  This is some of the best acting on film.  The story is told so brilliantly that it is worthy of its' subject, the immortal author of "Breakfast At Tiffany's" and "In Cold Blood," which is the period of his life the film focuses on.  Like a great novel, this film breathes - it does not do our thinking for us and it does not need to tell us how to feel at any point.  Like a well written novel, it assumes the reader (or, viewer) can think.  It is full of subtlety.Hoffman is Capote.  Capote was one of those rare, charismatic individuals that could captivate a room full of people just by entering.  He could hold them captive with his tales and antics for hours.  He knew how to reach people.  He treated everyone as an individual and learned each person's personal language.  For some, that language may be shared experience, an expression of empathy or sympathy and for others it might be so simple and crude as money.  He was a strange, amazing little man and Hoffman succeeded at raising him from the grave.I hope to see more Hoffman after this, and in roles that are worthy of his sublime genius.  The "shart" thing ("What About Mary?) was funny, but so beneath a person of this stellar ability.
summary: A masterpiece of acting, full of wonderful surprises

reviewText: Okay, so there is no denying the fact that Philip Seymour Hoffman nailed his performance as Truman Capote; he has the Oscar to prove it; but what I adore so much about `Capote' is that it never rests heavy on the shoulders of one man.  It never once allows the magnitude of Hoffman's performance remain the only redeeming factor of the film.  The script, the direction, the supporting actors, the score, the cinematography; everything is top notch and just as memorable as the lead performance.  In fact, the best thing about this movie is the masterful direction from Bennett Miller (who should have won the Oscar in my opinion).`Capote' catalogs the journey author Truman Capote took in order to pen his last completed `novel'; `In Cold Blood'.  `In Cold Blood' was the first `non-fiction novel'; based on the harrowing Clutter family murders; and proved to make Capote a household name.  Despite this great achievement, the experience took its toll on Truman and reduced him to a mere shell of his former self.Miller shoots the film in a very distilled and serene manner; creating a true sense of lucid menacing.  The film is shot in muted tones, the coloring dull; the voices almost hushed and this adds so many layers to the mood of the film.  Mychael Danna's score is yet another masterful facet of the film; its fragile, almost brittle piano strings playing perfect compliment to the grace of the film.  Adam Kimmel beautifully constructs the films cinematography, creating an eerie vibe that permeates each and every scene.  The gritty construction of the garments worn; the broken down and haunting way the sets were designed; everything about this film complemented one another brilliantly.`Capote' is the type of film I refer to as a `mood' film, for it relays a certain emotion so well you can't help but succumb to its advances.As the film follows Truman Capote; making his way to Kansas, investigating the horrible crime, interviewing the locals, familiarizing himself with the accused; we sense his obsession and his overall selfish desires that deride any and all good that could have come from this adventure.  `Capote' does a standup job of fleshing out the man that is Truman Capote, making him very real to us and exposing him for who he truly was; a man self concerned and manipulative.  His relationships are bare and open for the viewer, which helps shed a light on his somewhat ambiguous actions.  His motives may not always appear clear, for he was a very subtle yet conniving man; but with a keen eye one begins to understand and comprehend just what this man was all about.So now we've come to the acting.  Yes, Philip Seymour Hoffman was astonishing; utterly phenomenal.  His performance gets better and better for me each and every time I watch the film.  The way he says so much with the blank stare; the expressionless face that pierces through the audience and sings like a bird.  There is a scene, probably my favorite scene in the film, where Capote visits the morgue.  His face, that stagnant expression as he lifts the mother's coffin lid and pears in at the body, is priceless.  While I still feel that Heath Ledgers monumental achievement in `Brokeback Mountain' was superior work, I can't really complain about Hoffman's Oscar win; he truly was amazing here.But Hoffman is not the only one.Catherine Keener received a lot of attention for her subtle supporting role as Nelle Harper Lee.  She really develops her character nicely; but like everyone else on the screen, she falls into the background whenever Hoffman is on the screen.  Chris Cooper turns in a very fine performance as well as Bruce Greenwood; but it is Clifton Collins Jr., the accused, who is able to hold his own against Hoffman.  As Perry Smith, the murderer for whom Capote strikes an oddly perverse relationship, Clifton is able to really get under this mans skin, into his mind and formulate his every action.  It's a superb performance that sadly went underappreciated.In closing I just want to say that `Capote' is a superbly crafted gem of a film; a biopic that fleshes out its characters and delivers a masterful impression on the audience.  Miller is a marvelous director who captures the heart and soul of his subject; taking many risks in his portrayal and never condescending to sugarcoat or mask over the important details.  When we read Capote's words at the end of the film; "More tears are shed for answered prayers than unanswered ones"; we are shell-shocked with savage grief because we know those words to be true.  The entire film is haunting, chilling even, and the aftereffect is one that will stay with you long after the film has ended.
summary: An answered prayer indeed; one truly remarkable film...

reviewText: No review I write here is going to top that of C.B. Collins, Jr.'s spotlight review - that's about the best summary of a movie I've read on amazon.com.  I especially like the articulation of the element of the film I had been trying to wrap words around: that director Bennett Miller expertly juxtaposes the descent of Capote with the ascent of best friend, the unassuming Harper Lee.What's truly fascinating when watching 'Capote' is realizing that after 'In Cold Blood,' Capote *never* finished another piece of work.  He suffered through 22 years of complete artistic constipation.  By the time most people of my age got to know him, Capote was a freak show - a drunken, pill-popping sham who subsisted only through talk show appearances.Director Miller, screenwriter Dan Futterman and biographer Gerald Clarke make clear that 'In Cold Blood' scarred Capote.  He literally sold his soul to mold and finish the book he wanted.  He never recovered.  Miller depicts the essence of the roots of Capote's long, slow fall into irrelevance.And for all the talk about Hoffman's performance (he deserved that Oscar), the real breakout story here is Clifton Collins, Jr. as Perry Smith.  His is a truly mesmerizing performance.
summary: The roots of Capote's long, slow fall into irrelevance

reviewText: Average-height Phil Hoffman quickly has us believing he's the diminutive author ofIN COLD BLOODin CAPOTE, the story of Truman Capote's agonies to complete the very first true crime novel, one that was originally intended as only aNEW YORKERmagazine article.Clifton Collins is most convincing as condemned killer Perry Smith, who enters into a relationship with Capote under the strangest of circumstances: within the confines of a jail cell. Smith emotionally manipulates the trusting author into aiding an ultimately futile battle to overturn his death sentence. Only when time is running out for him does Perry reveal to his friend the psychopath that he really is. The effect upon Truman of Smith's graphic confession is as if he were also ascending the gallows stairs. (We learn in postscript that Capote never completed another book after IN COLD BLOOD and that his death was related to long-term alcohol damage.)Kudos also to Catherine Keener's Harper Lee. The author ofTO KILL A MOCKINGBIRDwas a close friend of Truman's since childhood. When necessary, she exerts a stabilizing influence upon him and possesses an emotional maturity that seems beyond the reach of flighty Capote.Rural Canada stands in well for Kansas farm country. The filmmakers and cast do an admirable job of recreating a world that's one-half century in the past and telling what is in the end a melancholy story.Parenthetical number preceding title is a 1 to 10 IMDb viewer poll rating.(7.4) Capote (Canada/USA-2005) - Philip Seymour Hoffman/Clifton Collins Jr./Catherine Keener/Chris Cooper/Bruce Greenwood/Mark Pellegrino
summary: It's as if Perry and I grew up in the same house, and one day he stood up and went out the back door while I went out the front.

reviewText: Rest in Peace, Phillip Seymour Hoffman.Hoffman was always a compelling presence on the screen, always spellbinding and interesting. His taste in roles was always impressive, and no matter how small the role, he never, ever cashed in, but gave it his best and acted with passion.We'll always remember him in Boogie Nights, The Talented Mr. Ripley, Synecdoche, New York, Red Dragon, Capote, and The Master. Hoffman gave us brilliant performance after brilliant performance, until we believed him utterly incapable of giving us a performance short of spellbinding.He eschewed the Hollywood spotlight, and remained down to earth and accessible. Hoffman was a man who battled dark demons that eventually took his life. The prospect of a Hollywood without him is dark indeed. Phillip, your death is tragic and felt by all. Our sympathies and prayers, knowing they can never make up, go to your wife and three children.We miss you, Phillip. Rest in Peace.Phillip Seymour Hoffman (1967 - 2014)P.S. Post to the comments your memories of PSH onscreen, and let this review be a tribute to the great man.
summary: Rest in peace, Phillip Seymour Hoffman.

reviewText: Most of the acclaim went to Phillip Seymour Hoffman for his portrayal of Truman Capote. But I think just as much credit should go to director Bennett Miller. For this to be his debut narrative film, Miller did a wonderful job. He knew what pace and mood to set for the story. I also love the script which didn't spell everything out for the audience. Capote's motives and feelings become murky allowing someone to make their own personal judgments about Capote. Hollywood bio-pics usually glorify the individual it shows to the point of masking their humanity (with all its flaws). But this took a different approach. I felt sympathetic for Capote and at the same time repulsed by his actions. A well done film!

reviewText: I enjoyed this movie very much, but I would not recommend it to others without mentioning that the pace of the movie is "controlled." Other viewer reviews on this page find the film to be glacial, boring, or a snoozefest. To be sure, this film has a lot of quiet in it. There are lots of long takes, reaction shots, and pauses. Background music is generally absent. This was a conscious choice on the director's part, and it worked for me.I've read and admired IN COLD BLOOD, and as that "nonfiction novel" is the backbone of this movie, I had a pre-existing interest level in the material. Others who might enjoy it include folks who have read TO KILL A MOCKINGBIRD, or subscribe to THE NEW YORKER, or don't mind a slowly-told story with absolutely killer (no pun intended) acting.As for myself, as a kid I remember Truman Capote as an odd and boozy guest on TV talk shows. Who was this strange man with the lisping Southern accent? This film taught me how this extraordinarily gifted writer's greatest success led to his ruin. It was fascinating to someone like me, who had only known the "ruin," not the man.
summary: Brilliant acting and stately pacing in a movie that is not for everyone.

reviewText: Philip Seymour Hoffman's performance as Truman Capote in this film is amazing, but the film itself is just as interesting. Its story focuses on Capote from when he first learns of the Clutter murders to the publication of his book about them and their killers , IN COLD BLOOD. It shows him constantly at odds with himself, negotiating morally over how to deal with the real people involved in the crime. For the book to be good, Capote knows that he has to get close to everyone involved. Thus, he tries to balance a personal relationship with the killers, particularly Perry Smith, while also hoping the state will execute them so that his book has a true ending. Capote essentially drives himself mad trying to compromise being an impartial journalist and a sympathetic human being, but watching his descent is fascinating. As he continues writing IN COLD BLOOD, the movie shows us a contrast to his struggle, the rise in fame of Capote's childhood friend Harper Lee, played sharply by Catherine Keener. At times, the film is funny, uncompromisingly dark and always fascinating.

reviewerName: Ben Wand "I used to be cool..."
reviewText: Philip Symour Hoffman is a good actor, and his performance in this movie is good, but not good enough to make it worthwhile. There are two keys to why this movie doesn't work:1. There is no conflict/climax. The thin story revolves around Truman's research and subsequent struggle with writing his book, but a short time into the movie the viewer soon says "who cares?" because there's nothing at stake. You're not rooting for or against anyone.2. We've seen this type of movie before (several times). You know the type - murderers are captured, and there's a person with influence who befriends/falls in love/sympathizes with the killers, and mourns them when they are executed. The difference between those movies and Capote is that they are vastly better, not to mention that the concept of convicted killers being shown as victims is troubling as it is, and is an irresponsible message.In all, this is a boring re-tread of a movie, especially if you are unfamiliar with Truman Capote (which most of us are). Sorry, but a writer who was popular in the early '60s has no appeal to anyone under 45. Avoid this movie. Honestly, why this was so popular with the academy had nothing to do with the quality of the movie.

reviewText: Capote is a snapshot of the author at a certain point in time, and not a full length biography, which disappointed me at first, but, its brevity does not diminish its excellence. The action solely revolves around Truman being sent to Kansas to investigate the Clutter family murders for The New Yorker. He brings with him his lifelong friend, Harper Lee, who served as his research assistant. Once the movie begins, it is a challenge to pause. Phillip Seymour Hoffman put forth tremendous effort to recreate on screen (and I think accurately) one of the most distinctive personalities of our time. His charm was well-known and infectious and, most probably, completely fabricated. As a man, Capote may have had much in common with the killers of "In Cold Blood." He was a pathological liar and didn't seem to have much of an interest in the suffering, or existence, of others. You get a glimpse of his lack of empathy when he goes to Harper Lee's party for To Kill a Mockingbird and doesn't notice her or extend his congratulations for her achievement. Another reflection of his soul comes at the outset when he tells the Kansas police sheriff that he doesn't care about who the killers are or if they'll ever be caught. The police are taken aback and the sheriff tells him, "Well, I do." People were merely props for Capote, and he used them his entire life. Although it covers only a few year's time, this work tells us much about who the man really was.

reviewText: This was not an easy movie to watch.  It shows the length a writer will go to, using conniving promises and deceit for his own benefit.  This was one of the first books I read to the very end in the late Sixties.  It was in such detail that it was hard to visualize how strangers could do such a thing to an ordinary family.  It took place in November, 1959, in Kansas and made the news even in New York City.This thoroughly corrupt magazine writer took the train all the way to Kansas to research for an article.  He had no restraints in his intrusion on the privacy of the dead, opening the hardwood caskets and describing how the victims appeared and the clothes they wore in death for a closed casket funeral.  He spent three months there attending the trial, then returned to New York to talk, talk, talk about every little detail.  He said he was talking his head off.  He talked incessantly about the case and his attachment to Perry Smith, the triggerman with no conscience.They had much in common.  Perry, whose mother was a Cherokee Indian, grew up in an orphanage.  Truman was deserted by his mother as a child and left with some aunts in Alabama.  He used his wiles to convince Perry that he will make him less than a monster in the book he plans to write.  Perry thinks Capote is a friend, but he continually lied to him about the book using cruelty to get his way.  "People remember first impressions" and "be careful what you do to get what you want."Capote's lover, Jack Dunphy, gave him an ultimatum to come to Spain where he will be writing his own book; he abandoned the murderers in prison out in Leavenworth for "love," even though he admitted that he felt a kinship with Perry.After three years with the book two-thirds finished, he had a public reading in a New York theater and received a standing ovation for his snooping in Kansas and his imaginative "non-fiction" novel.  He finally got his confession from Perry who told the details to clear his conscience, but it was just fodder for the book.  IN COLD BLOOD was built on tainted blood, of the deranged killers who were after money (found only $40-50 in the house), and Perry was the one who did the shootings.  By the execution date in April, 1965, Capote was a basket case but the inmates were cool and collected.  He cried crocodile tears as he was not a friend.  Another writer, Harper Lee, told him "the fact is you didn't want to save them."  The book was published in 1966.The dial telephones were a good touch as that is what we had back then.  In the apartment he shared in New York with Jack, the bed was an antique like Margaret Butler's.  Arby Lockhart looked like I did in 1965 as she portrayed the wife of the sheriff, who was also duped by Capote and had invited him into his own home for Christmas.  He was an unethical reporter and socialite where he drank too much.  He had been damaged because "people judge you by the way you talk."  This movie brought the book to life better as it dwelt more on the actions of the writer and less on the murders.
summary: Good Performances but No Morals Anywhere.

reviewText: Truman Capote was for a time, famous for being famous..Moreso, since Capote had written "Breakfast At Tiffany's" at an astonishingly precocious age, a title he pirated from a wealthy confidante who told him about a sexual encounter he'd had with a sailor, and the next morning Capote's friend said to his guest, "Brunch is on me at the finest restaurant you can name", and the seaman said, "Well, let's have breakfast at Tiffany's!"..Capote, like all resourceful writers salted that away, for that useful rainy day..It was a title in search of a novel..And that's how Capote worked, he imagined a scenario and spent months constructing it in his sub-conscious mind, then went into seclusion and wrote like the devil..Capote stumbled upon the senseless killing of an an upright, God fearing family in Kansas while perusing the backpages of the New York Times, and realized there was sensational value in the story, and intended to write how the murders affected the community, regardless if the perpetrators were ever captured..Capote told his editor he was leaving for Kansas immediately, and would take Harper Lee, author of "To Kill a Mockingbird", along as his research assistant..Nell, Harper Lee, would prove invaluable to Capote since she had an engaging ability to charm a rural community already on extreme edge since the incident, and was less shocking than Truman upon introduction..Capote met Alvin Dewey, the Bureau agent in charge of capturing the killers and told him he needed carte blanche to the police files, but was not concerned if the killers were found, he only wanted to write how the town was holding up!..Dewey told Capote, "Well, I do care, Herb Clutter was my friend"..In the end, Capote used his contagious charm to defrost the community, and was granted first person status, above all other journalists covering the crime, in fact Capote wrote a friend, "People here initially rejected me, but now I'm practically the Mayor."..When Capote and Nell first spyed Perry Smith and Dick Hickok in court at their arraignment, Capote told Nell, "Look, Perry Smith's feet barely touch the ground."..Nell told a friend, "Oh my God, this is the beginning of an intense love affair between Truman and Perry"..While writing "In Cold Blood", Truman changed course and realized the article intended for The New Yorker would become a narrative novel, since the subject matter expanded, and his editors agreed..Six years hence in utter agony "In Cold Blood" was published, and Capote was the recipient of adulation not seen since Hemingway wrote "The Old Man and the Sea"..The net result became, Capote had the wealth and celebrity to finance his disintegration, and never finished another novel..Capote died alone at the home of Joanne Carson, wife of late night talk show host Johnny Carson at the age of 59, suffering from acute alcoholism and drug addiction, perhaps because he never recovered from the trauma inflicted on himself from "expoiting" Perry Smith, who died compliments of the state of Kansas, from a hangman's noose, for the shotgun murders of the Herb Clutter family, for a score of 29 dollars, and a transistor radio.
summary: Can you really eat  "Breakfast at Tiffany's?"

reviewText: This film is a generally excellent piece of realism about writer Truman Capote and the making of his early 1960s "non-fiction novel" about the murder of a Kansas farm family, In Cold Blood.  The performances, cinematography, design, pacing, and (for the most part) direction and editing cannot be faulted.  My problem is the moral premise as embodied in the script.The script sets up Capote's childhood friend, author Harper Lee of To Kill a Mockingbird fame, as his co-worker and moral conscience, esentially convicting him of exploiting the killers on death row, "wanting them dead" finally so that Capote could publish the book.  I have no idea if this indictment of Capote derived from Harper Lee, who is an admirable figure and admirably portayed.  But even if true, the conclusion borders on the glib, and is questionable.  The essential fault of the movie is that it builds this indictment of Capote as a writer, but does not give him equally resonant words to justify his methods or ends.  It simply assumes that fame, writing a best seller, etc, is a bad and inferior motive.  And it assumes that was Capote's motive.Capote was a weird, quirky enough figure and is rather easily parodied.  He was a marginal, desperately lonely figure, mawkish, embarrassing, somewhat perverse.  But what he was doing was a literary experiment.  It took somebody like him to enter this no man's land.  The book was successful in its own right and on its own merits.  It has indeed had an influence on American art and literature, some very good and some bad.  But the experimental nature of the project was bound to incur unknown personal and psychological costs and risks.  Art is necessary for any mature society to see itself, and while that premise does not justify any art or any experiment, it is enough to justify a serious endeavor like In Cold Blood.Secondly, the charge of Capote exploiting the killers is highly questionable.  They were clearly guilty, had due process of law, and the idea either that (1) Capote could have done more for them, i.e., getting better lawyers for more appeals, or (2) such appeals would have been justified or successful, is really highly questionable.  One cannot impose present day legal ideals, or attitudes about capital punishment, ex post facto on the early 1960s.  There were trials in that day truly way out of line (the Sam Shepard carnival in Ohio upon which The Fugitive was based) which make better and fairer comparison than present day assumptions.  There is no evidence the Kansas killers were treated in anything but a sober and deliberate manner for those times, by the system.  Their execution was an inevitability.  And the so-called "lies" Capote told Perry Smith were not only either harmless (he personally hadn't settled on a book title), or weirdly humane (i.e., his sister still cared for him).  Are these the sort of sins with which we convict major art in this country these days?  If so, it says more about us -- a descent toward the trivially personal over 45 years, with a tendancy to send people up the flagpole for derision.  Both tendancies were notably absent from Capote's final product, by the way, as to all concerned -- whatever misdemeanors (or mere infractions) he may have committed along the way.But you do not have to like Truman Capote personally, or even like his book, to believe that his cause deserved more of a voice in this project.  The fact is, the plain people of Kansas gave the In Cold Blood killers a fairer trial than this film does Truman Capote.  Thus for all its great aesthetic merits, which carry it far, this film is ultimately not satisfying as either an unbiased record or as a moral tale.

reviewText: `capote', the biopic of a few years in the life of novelist and short story writer, Truman Capote, directed by Bennett Miller, and starring Phillip Seymour Hoffman, for which he won the Best Actor Academy Award, is very much of an `insider's movie with strong influences from it's primary subject, Capote's `nonfiction novel', `In Cold Blood'.For starters, the director and writer, Dan Futterman, take a very minimalist approach to their subject. For a film about a writer, there seem to be remarkably few words spoken in the script. This may have been a big mistake for the sake of many viewers. Even though my mother lived through Capote's height of celebrity with many appearances on the talk show circuit, she was totally unfamiliar with what he had written, even though she was quite familiar with both the magazine `The New Yorker' and the novel and movie, `Breakfast at Tiffany's' for which Capote was most famous before `In Cold Blood'. Even if you knew of Capote, or at least knew more of his reputation than the Kansas locals he met at the outset of his research into the book, you may have had trouble identifying the other major literary characters appearing briefly on the screen, such as Harper Lee, the author of `To Kill a Mockingbird' and Capote's assistant on his trips to Kansas, Bill Shawn (played by Bob Balaban), the Editor in Chief of `The New Yorker', and Richard Avedon, the extremely talented and influential fashion photographer who, until his recent death, did almost all the photographs for `The New Yorker'. The role of Capote's companion who we meet only through telephone conversations between he and Capote, is even more subtle, as this individual could easily be either Capote's agent or simply a colleague.This movie seems to me to be extremely similar in style to the recent Coppola / Bill Murray film, `Lost in Translation', which also has sparse dialogue and very little character development. That is not to say there is no significant character development in `capote', especially on the part of Capote himself. The perps of the Clutter murders had a profound effect on Capote, expecially Perry Smith, the more articulate of the two. And yet, in spite of the fact that Capote's interest in the case was to some extent responsible for various stays of execution and improved legal representation, Capote always put completing his book ahead of their fates. As Hoffman and Miller state in some of the commentary, Capote wanted them to be executed not so much because they were guilty as because it would enable to wrap up the story of his book.The DVD package includes my favorite special feature, that is, voiceover commentaries by the director and star and the director and cinematographer. In my experience, this is the only extra which is often worth troubling with, expecially in a movie with such a narrow focus. All the `making of' featurettes often simply repeat what you get first hand in the comments, unless it happens to be a special effects action fest where you need the specialist's point of view on how, for example, Andy Serkis did Gollum or King Kong.The very best thing about this movie is Hoffman's portrayal of Capote, which is probably only really interesting if you happen to have seen him on TV or know a lot about his work. I have the feeling that aside from major cinema fans, this movie may be lost on the average movie audience used to the richness in George Lucas / Stephen Spielberg / Peter Jackson ourves.The fact is, I enjoyed this movie a lot, but that is probably because I am well versed in the history of both the author, `The New Yorker', Capote's connection to the magazine, and his connection to this crime.
summary: Great cinematic and dramatic artistry. A bit of an insider's view

reviewText: Truman Capote's masterpiece IN COLD BLOOD (1965) set a new standard and style in the literary world. We know that he didn't finish another novel after it, too, which begs the question, "Why?"Fast-forward to the 2005 film CAPOTE and we get the answer.Mr. Capote is reincarnated in the body of actor Philip Seymour Hoffman, and it is "through" him that we get to find out what happened during this snapshot time of Truman Capote's life. A vicious murder of a family in rural Kansas takes place and Truman races there to find out if there's a magazine story in it. But what he finds is much more than just a short periodical piece. As the murderers are captured, Truman becomes enraptured with the idea of learning why these seemingly innocuous men did something so heinous.Truman digs deep, perhaps too deep, and we watch as every shred of decency is stripped away from him just so he can "finish the story." He bribes the prison warden and lies to the two killers (and ultimately to himself) about why he's really spending so much time with them on death row.In the end, it rips Truman apart, causing him to become an alcoholic and a shell of what he once was.______________________________________________________________________________Occasionally casting directors get "it" right. And this time, they not only got it right by casting Mr. Hoffman in the role of Truman Capote, they bottled a bit of magic and captured it on film. David Strathairn did it, too, in his performance as Edward R. Murrow in GOOD NIGHT AND GOOD LUCK, but Hoffman takes it to a euphoric level for movie watchers. His mannerisms, voice and costumes were impeccable. Many times I thought I was actually watching Truman Capote and not an actor playing him. Now that's great acting.If there was any failings in the movie, I'd have to say it was with its overall script. Although intriguing and genuinely creepy, it held only a small piece of what Truman Capote was. I realize that to capture all of what he was would be almost impossible ...but there you go. That's life.Even so, Hoffman deserves all the accolades he's gotten and I have no doubt he'll jump up on stage at the Oscars this year and pick up his statue.

reviewText: "Capote" is a movie that sticks with you days after watching it. The screenplay is as gripping and exciting as a fictional mystery, yet it builds on the true account of how Truman Capote came to writeIn Cold Blood-- a new genre he dubbed the "non-fiction novel".After reading the New York Times article on the murder of a farming family in Holcomb, Kansas in 1959, Capote travels there with childhood friend Harper Lee, author of To kill a Mocking bird, on the premise of writing an article for the magazine "The New Yorker". In the process he befriends Alvin Dewey (Chris Cooper) who heads the Kansas Bureau of Investigation and a number of townspeople. The killers, Perry Smith (Clifton Collins) and Richard Hickock, are caught and convicted.Capote visits them in prison and helps obtain a lawyer for their appeal, but eventually becomes obsessed with Smith. He sees him as a vulnerable, sensitive and misunderstood man; someone who he can relate to -- alone, troubled and sad. By the time their appeals are rejected and they are headed for the gallows, Capote is overwhelmed with grief, perhaps personal guilt for using them to write his "non-fiction novel". It is a tragedy one supposes Capote never overcame, considering no major work from him appeared after "In Cold Blood". Ironically, he, too, in a way became a victim.To visually convey the brutality of the subject matter, a number of images are startlingly realistic, and stay with you long after the movie ends. Among these is Truman Capote opening the wooden casket of the murdered Mrs. Clutter, dressed in blue, her faced wrapped entirely in cotton. So too is the bloody and violent slashing of Mr. Clutter's throat and the shotgun blasts to the heads of the Clutter family. The hanging of Perry Smith, which begins with heavy breathing quickens as he is about to be executed, is an experience the viewer practically lives. And finally, after he is dropped from the trap door, his body jerks momentarily, then  it is still forever -- a scene chillingly reminiscent of the movieIn Cold Blood.Moreover, it is Philip Seymour Hoffman who immerses himself in the persona of Truman Capote. He assumes Capote's appearance and quirky demeanour, complete with raspy voice and mannerisms, with such convincing perfection. It is little wonder he has garnered a host of accolades, including a Golden Globe and Oscar. He is simply brilliant!

reviewText: Capote is the story of author Truman Capote (Phillip Seymour Hoffman) and the events leading up to his publication of his best and last novel, "In Cold Blood." While reading the newspaper, Truman stumbles upon an article of the senseless killing of a family in Kansas. Originally planning on writing an article for his magazine The New Yorker, Truman finds that there is much more to his story than he first imagined after talking to one of the killers, Perry Smith (Clifton Collins Jr.). The further Capote goes to get the truth of that horrible night, the more he starts to lose it as he falls for Perry and becomes detached from everyone around him eventually making him a recluse and a total alcoholic. Hoffman gives the performance of his career portraying the eccentric and funny sounding Capote and Catherine Keener is excellent as Capote's best friend and fellow author Nelle Harper Lee, writer of "To Kill a Mockingbird." While the performances are well done and convincing, the movie and the plot are never outstanding. The drama, the alcohol, the falling in love--they never seem any more interesting than typical Oscar-season fare. Capote doesn't ever come off as more than a good drama that is well acted by very capable actors and while that may not please people hearing nothing but rave reviews about how amazing the movie is, it's worth it to see the actors stretch out and give their thoroughly convincing performances.

reviewText: Simply said, this movie stands as an example of quality film making.Based on Gerald Clarke's biography of the famous writer, Dan Futterman's screenplay focuses in on Capote's late 50's-early 60's period and the conflicted relationship he developed with killer Perry Edward Smith during his research for what would become his best-known work, IN COLD BLOOD.Philip Seymour Hoffman is phenomenal. He's transformed into Capote, showing a coldly manipulating underside to the colorful writer who was world famous for his humorous socializing antics and talk show schmoozefests.Great performances also from Catherine Keener as Nell Harper Lee (TO KILL A MOCKINGBIRD), Clifton Collins Jr. as Perry Edward Smith, and Chris Cooper as Kansas detective Alvin Dewey.

reviewText: Believe me when I tell you that this is one of the best films of the year. It is a complex and multi-layered work of art. Truman Capote, under assignment from the New Yorker magazine, explores a terrible murder of a family of four in the American heartland. He asks his childhood friend from Monroeville Alabama, Nelle Harper Lee, to act as his assistant and together they will explore the murder and its impact on the community for a magazine article. Phillip Seymour Hoffman delivers the acting performance of the year playing the role of the cognitively unique Capote. Catherine Keener was superb playing the solid strength of Harper Lee.When the killers are soon caught and Capote sees the half-Native American Perry Smith, an odd chemistry develops and Capote becomes obsessed with Smith. Yet Capote manipulates the two murderers and even pays for their first court appeal in order to obtain more information for the article that has now developed into a book. Clifton Collins is excellent in the role of Perry Smith and Chris Cooper is excellent as the head of the Kansas division of the FBI.Capote had a rare gift, the ability to make himself totally vulnerable through painful self revelation, so as to obtain entry into soul of his target. He does this with Smith and they begin a careful relationship whereby they reveal themselves to each other like chess players, each making careful calculated moves so as to obtain the maximum amount of information and manipulation of the other party.Harper Lee confronts Capote asking whether he has fallen in love with Perry Smith, but Capote says that he and Smith are the same person, only Capote ran out the 'front door' and Smith ran out the 'back door".Capote names his book "In Cold Blood" but keeps this information from Perry Smith. Eventually you begin to realize that cold blood is the mental state that Capote had to assume to manipulate the killers long enough to extract the full story of the murders from them.As the book nears completion, Capote begins a mental breakdown. He may actually love Perry Smith and thus regrets his death but also he knows the execution must occur to bring closure to the book so it can be published. Thus when Capote wishes Smith to die he is cast into guilt and grief; but when he wishes Smith to live, he is cast into depression over the lack of closure of his masterpiece.One of the most wise plot devices in this film was to contrast the fall of Capote with the rise of Harper Lee and her wonderful novel "To Kill A Mockingbird".  Capote sinks into depression and alcoholism laced with mounting self pity while Harper Lee gains acclaim first for her novel and then for the film starring Gregory Peck. On the night of the gala opening of "To Kill A Mockingbird" Capote attends the festivities in a drunken depressed stupor and is so self absorbed that he can't even offer his supportive best friend, Lee, congratulations on her novel and film.What do we make of this film?  It is incredibly well done and demonstrates that no act of mercy is totally pure, no act of cruelty is totally evil.  It was Capote's incredible skills that allowed him to manipulate the killers to gain the story that made him the most famous American living writer; but he sold his soul to buy the story and he never recovered from the wound.This is mature film-making at its best!
summary: The rise and fall of a great talent

reviewText: Capote is a daring motion picture.The film is an examination of the creative process, what it means to be a writer. But that isn't what makes it daring. What makes Capote daring is that it doesn't take a deconstructionist approach to the subject matter. In this age of hip, irreverent self-referentialism, the conventional approach would have been to have Truman Capote step in and out of his own story, talking directly to the audience about his state of mind in an effort to give the film a sardonic edge. Capote doesn't do this; it follows a linear narrative structure, depending on mood, facial expressions, subtle dialogue and somber interaction to make its points. As a result, it is a more captivating thesis on writing than, say, Adaptation(not that Adaptation isn't good).Capote takes the audience on a dense journey into a writer's mind, particularly the ugly side, the insecurities, the egotism, the exploitation of  close acquaintances, the damaged relationships, the detached facades, the emotional coldness and moral ambivalence. Despite all that, Truman Capote comes across as a likable character. Flawed, without a doubt, but undeniably intriguing.I haven't even mentioned Philip Seymour Hoffman's indelible performance. I'm convinced that his Capote is the kind of performance that will be talked about for years. Whether or not it is an accurate depiction of the real Truman Capote is practically irrelevant(I've heard that it is, but I'm not familiar enough with the character to make that call). What matters is that Hoffman manages such a complete transformation of his voice and mannerisms while not coming across as an overdone caricature, and that he communicates so much both nonverbally and through the WAY he says things rather than what he actually says. In real life, there is a constant dichotomy between what people say and what they really feel, really mean. Few films explore this, but Hoffman's performance is a textbook example of complex acting, creating a multi-dimensional character.Capote isn't a perfect film. The music score is hackneyed and many scenes drag on longer than they need to. Minor quibbles when the overall impact is so powerful. This is one of the must-see films of 2005.

reviewText: This movie is not easy.  It appeared that Capote was sympathetic to at least one of the killers, and yet he took advantage of them for his own personal reasons.  He lied to them, and he took himself away from them after he had seemingly built up a mutual friendship.This odd little fellow had the ability to get through to practically everyone he came in contact with, from the NYC literary world to a local Kansas lawman to at least one of these killers.Perhaps the secret to the man was seen in the closing scenes of the movie, when Truman appeared to be unquestionably sincere, and it was revealed that he never completed another book.This was an excellent performance by Hoffman, who became so much of the man I recognized as Capote, that I will never think of anyone else when I see him in another role . . he brought this complicated man to life.

reviewText: Capote is a rare thing: a beautifully shot film that subtly develops its characters through action and dialogue.And that's really about it.It's not necessarily a bad thing, though. The story's okay, and the acting is good, of course, but those things are not nearly as compelling as the way this film develops the character of Truman Capote. I think what I like best about this character development is that the movie doesn't try to be an all-encompassing biography likeRay (Widescreen Edition). It gives us a snapshot into Capote's life by showing him during a four-year period, concentrating almost completely on the writing ofIn Cold Blood. It's not a biopic by any means, and yet I think it defines Truman Capote much better than most biopics do with their main characters. Give me a subtle movie like Capote over a drawn out life of a celebrity any day.I'm not saying it's perfect, for in some ways, the story drags on. As Capote waits to find out what happens to the killers, we the audience wait with him, wondering what will happen. It's kind of like being stuck on the ship in the middle of the Atlantic inMaster and Commander - The Far Side of the World (Widescreen Edition). The main character's in limbo, so we're in limbo, too. But Capote manages to pick up the pace again rather quickly, and we watch with Capote as he witnesses what appears to become a seminal event in his life. The events of the novel Capote writes aren't that interesting, either, and watching Capote become a part of the killers' lives is only partially interesting. It's the way the movie develops Capote with this one event that continually moves me.Watching this one event unfold and witnessing how it effects the main character is truly fascinating.
summary: An Episode in the Life of...

reviewText: First off, the acting in this film is top-notch 110% Oscar material, no doubt about it.  Second, if you're expecting a bio-pic, forget it, this is a romanticized account of famed American icon Capote and how his life was "forever changed" by the events that influenced his infamous novel, "In Cold Blood."  Great cinematography underlines the moody and stark themes contained within.  My only complaint:  the film tries to cover too much, too quickly, with mixed results.  For example, the empathy Capote feels for the killers occurs with such rapidity it doesn't allow the audience to catch up...then there's the ongoing distraction of Capote's infectious personality, which could in all fairness, be a film within itself.  When all is said and done, it is quite difficult to care for these killers, given the heinousness of their crimes, especially when Perry retells how he slit the throat of the father...and the tragedy and humanity of it are only superficially hinted at so that the bottom line is that it just leaves one feeling, well, a bit inpatient (as Capote was) for it all to end.  Still, this film tries very hard to give a screenplay treatment to a myriad of feelings that might be better handled in a novel.  Also, given Harper Lee's reknowned reclusiveness, a big plus of this film is getting to know her....if in fact the portrayal is accurate (we will never really know)....Thematically, she is the conscience of the film, which is sort of an overused Atticus Finch analogy.  Overall, this film is a better rental than an item to own, but it is definitely a must see.
summary: Superb acting and cinematography very nearly hits mark

reviewText: CAPOTE explores what every writer must experience when they delve into the dark world of real crime. Guilt. Shame. Seclusion. Ridicule. Yet, it was an experience that Truman Capote had never encountered until he wrote IN COLD BLOOD. And as the movie CAPOTE portrays, his venture into this true-life Kansas Crime, may very well have been the very thing that eventually destroyed him.Philip Seymour Hoffman embodies Truman Capote in fine fashion and deserved the Oscar, without question. He takes on the role of Truman at the point of his career before he embarked on writing the book that would define his career, IN COLD BLOOD. He's a huge celebrity, movie star, life of the party and successful writer looking for his next story.The IN COLD BLOOD story has been told numerous times, but never from this angle. In CAPOTE, we get to see the story from Capote point of view. How he got the inside track? How he went from shunned and ignored in the little Kansas town, to friend with special insider priveledge to interview and get to know the witnesses, friends of the victims and of course, the killers.What we truly see, isn't how it's done, but what it did to Capote. How manipulating his way into the lives of the people in his book affected his personality and how becoming friends to the killers, misleading them as to what his true intentions were and then having to explain himself as he waited for them to be put to death.There's something incredibly deep, challenging and thought-provoking that comes across in Philip Seymour Hoffman's performance that it almost demands to be seen. This is a movie not to miss. A great movie... all around.
