reviewText: Author Truman Capote, he of fluff "Breakfast at Tiffany's" fame, throttled the literary world by going into an altogether different - and certainly uncharacteristic - direction in his subsequent work "In Cold Blood." But the direction his work took him, not only according to this unsettling bio-drama and other corraborative accounts, was into moral and ethical disintegration. And, by his life's end, Capote's post-"In Cold Blood" professional and personal meltdown cost him his very soul. Such is the excrutiating pain in this, screenwriter Dan Futterman's depiction of Capote's life in the seven-year period (1959-66) that "In Cold Blood" consumed Capote, beginning the weekend of Nov. 14, 1959, in America's rural Bible Belt where a farming family of four in Holcomb, Kan., was methodically slaughtered, and beyond the executions April 14, 1965, of the two killers. A New York Times story about the savage murders caught the attention of Capote, then a free lance writer for Vanity Fair and basking in his recent claim to fame courtesy of "Breakfast ..." From New York, Capote sets out for Kansas with a colleague, Harper Lee, herself unknowingly on the verge of literary acclaim with her work, "To Kill A Mockingbird." In gaining the trust and help of the locals despite his "flamboyancy," Capote also earns the same from his subjects, killers Perry Smith and Dick Hickock. But in getting what he needs from his subjects, Capote sacrifices both his professional and personal ethics and morals, and it is that which is the basis for this film, deservedly rated as one of 2005's best movies. In the title role, Philip Seymour Hoffman validates his Best Actor Oscar by ingeniously aoviding the pathetic parody that could have been made of Capote's life. So absolutely convincing is Hoffman as Capote that we have to remind ourselves that who we're seeing isn't the real man. "Capote," however, doesn't answer but alludes to why the real man sacrificed his moral and ethical direction, be it for another shot of self-serving fame or because he developed a risky - and costly - personal relationship with one of the killers (Smith). But the film doesn't claim to answer that question and instead focuses on the dynamics of Capote's meltdown. Caught in his fallout is co-writer Harper Lee, Capote's quiet voice of conscience and logic, and actress Catherine Keener serves up an Oscar-caliber performance as well. As Capote disintegrates privately, Lee rises professionaly to literary legend status with "To Kill A Mockingbird," and so self-abosrbed is Capote that he cannot share in his friend's professional success. And it is one of Capote's comments to himself, at the premier of the film version of Lee's literary masterpiece, that makes us uneasy with what Capote had apparently become: of his colleague's novel, Capote mutters, "I frankly don't see what the fuss is all about." By film's end, after the execution of both his subjects, Capote is on a plane headed back to New York and - we also are led to conclude - into irretrievable moral and ethical condemnation. In portraying Capote, Hoffman superbly rises above mere mimicking of his subject and presents Capote as a complex and psychologically torn but self-absorbed man who got too close as a writer to his story's sources and, in the process, tragically compromised his own soul. Through it all, however, and years after Capote's death, "In Cold Blood" nonetheless has gained classic status and, arguably perhaps, Capote never bettered himself before or after. And this film is justly regarded as one of the best of 2005, and it and Hoffman's unsettling but masterful performance are must-see's.

reviewText: For just a while, "Capote" is a book lover's dream.Completely aside from the fact that the film documents the creation of Truman Capote's tainted masterpiece, "In Cold Blood," it also flits quickly and tantalizingly through his world and the literary scene of New York, 1960 -- there's "The New Yorker" editor William Shawn; that's photographer Richard Avedon; Harper Lee is even seen receiving word that her book, "To Kill A Mockingbird," has found a publisher.And in the midst of it all is the title character, a catty, fey figure whom we first see holding court at a crowded house party and dropping James Baldwin's name; but, as portrayed by Philip Seymour Hoffman, he's still a pretty charming show-off.Fairly soon, however, he's compelled to write about a mass murder in Kansas, where a family of four has been shotgunned in its remote country home, and as he awkwardly investigates the crime, the movie's temperature drops gradually and considerably.Capote, however, is too filled with glee over finding such rich story material to accurately process the tragedy. It's not until he befriends one of the killers, Perry Smith (Clifton Collins Jr.), that the crimes and their repercussions really begin to affect him and, eventually, seem to poison him.Screenwriter Dan Futterman has adapted Gerald Clarke's biography in a straightforward manner that feels a little like a procedural, and first-time director Bennett Miller has a real touch for capturing washed-out rooms, haunted faces and gloomily atmospheric landscapes. No matter when or where you see it, "Capote" is a chilly Sunday night of a movie.The actors are equally low-key and deft. Collins (who looks a little like Robert Downey Jr. sharing the same face with Steve Buscemi) drifts swiftly between seeming sympathetic and shamelessly pragmatic; and Catherine Keener is endearing, if a little underused, as Harper Lee.But as good as all the other elements are, this is really Hoffman's show. He's built differently than Capote (he's an inch under six feet and Capote was 5'3") but Miller uses seamless techniques to make him appear smaller than his surroundings. The rest of the performance, however, is no trick: Hoffman both channels the author's famous quirks and presents a spot-on portrait of a writer who gets exactly what he hoped for, but figures out too late it wasn't at all what he needed.
summary: "...He headed for home, and the day's work, unaware that it would be his last." (3.5 stars)

reviewText: At the start of the movie, I would have given a lot to be standing next to Truman Capote at his party, both of us half drunk, listening to his anecdotes and trading quips with him. At the end of the movie, I wouldn't have wanted to be in the same room with him.Capote is a major motion picture, in my view, with a great, mesmerizing performance by Philip Seymour Hoffman as Capote. Hoffman doesn't just mimic Capote's languid lisp and effeminate mannerisms. He captures the man's drive, his ambition, his empathy, his charm, his determination to get what he wants. What Capote wants is to write a book, and the book is going to be the story of the slaughter of the Clutter family in Holcomb, Kansas, by two drifters, Richard Hickock (Mark Pellegrino) and Perry Smith (Clifton Collins, Jr.). The two broke into the Clutter's home because they'd heard there was $10,000 hidden. They tied up Herb Clutter and his 15-year-old son, Kenyon, and took them to the basement. They tied up Bonnie Clutter and the 16-year-old daughter, Nancy, and left them upstairs. After searching the house and finding no hidden cash, Hickock intended to rape Nancy. Smith stopped him...but then slit Herb Clutter's throat and used a shotgun to blast his head. Then Smith used the shotgun on the son, the mother and the daughter. They left with only about $50.Capote and Harper Lee (Catherine Keener), a friend acting as his assistant, travel to Holcomb and spend three months talking to everyone they can find, from Alvin Dewey (Chris Cooper), the cop in charge, to the teen-agers who knew the young Clutters. After Hickock and Smith are captured, Capote develops a strange, almost intimate, relationship with Smith. "It's as if Perry and I grew up in the same house," he says at one point, "and one day he went out the back door and I went out the front." He is writing what he knows will be a great book, but it can have no ending until Perry finally breaks down and tells him what happened the night of the killings. And it still will have no end until, all appeals having failed, Hickock and Perry are hanged. Years go by. To get this story, Capote will use and manipulate Perry, a man more vulnerable than we might think. Capote lies to him, uses emotional blackmail, perhaps even believes himself some of the emotions he is displaying to Perry. But all the while, Capote's ambition and ruthlessness to write his story never waver, no matter how emotionally wrenching it has become for him. Of course, he does get the story, Perry and Hickock are hanged and In Cold Blood becomes one of the masterpieces of American literature.Hoffman manages to evoke a reluctant admiration for Capote. If you've ever seen the photo of Capote used on the dust jacket of his first novel, Other Voices, Other Rooms, there is no doubt that the man is flamboyant and amused by people's reaction to his distinctiveness. There's also no doubt that as a teen-ager, Capote probably was unmercifully treated by his peers. One can't help but admire Capote's talent and his single-mindedness, or be repelled by his willingness to do just about anything to get the story and write his book.Hoffman gives an extraordinary performance. Also excellent are so many others in the cast, particularly Chris Cooper, Clifton Collins, Jr. and Catherine Keener. If In Cold Blood is a book worth reading, Capote is a movie worth seeing.
summary: You May Not Admire Capote, But Philip Seymour Hoffman Gives A Great Performance

reviewText: P. S. Hoffman won a well-deserved Best Actor award for his turn as Truman Capote. After years of stealing the show from other actors, in work as diverse and good as his roles in Boogie Nights, Punch Drunk Love, and Owning Mahowny (and he was the only reason to see dreck like Along Came Polly), he now has his statue. He is excellent as Capote, who comes across as brilliant and charming, but also self-centered and very manipulative. At Harper Lee's party for her "To Kill a Mocking Bird," Capote sulks, drinks, and hisses, "I don't see what all the fuss is about." He can't share in the joy of his lifelong friend. It's all about him. He paid a high price for getting his story, however. What made Capote a superstar, the "non-fiction novel" "In Cold Blood," also sucked the life out him: he never wrote another book. In the film, we see a writer obsessed. Truman is in love with the doomed Perry Smith, but he wants even more to get, and tell, a great story. When he hears that Smith might have his execution delayed, Truman fears he'll have a "nervous breakdown." You might not like Truman Capote after seeing this movie, but you'll want to read him--if you haven't already--or read more of his books. Hoffman completely embodies his character. Without his great performance, the movie wouldn't have worked. But the supporting roles are well played, too. One of last year's best movies.

reviewText: Philip Seymour Hoffman was uncannily stunning in his mesmerizing Oscar worthy portrayal of celebrated author and personality Truman Capote, capturing all the nuances of his multi faceted personality.  Having seen Capote speak on many occasions Hoffman's speech patterns, mannerisms and appearance were eerily authentic.Hoffman's performance takes us through the point in Capote's career when he was researching and creating his highly acclaimed novel "In Cold Blood".  Capote looking for a new interesting subject was intrigued by the brutal shotgun slaying of a rural Kansas farming family of four.  Hastily embarking to Kansas accompanied by Catherine Keener, wonderfully playing childhood friend and esteemed author of "To Kill a Mockingbird", Harper Lee they proceed to interview all the important participants of the investigation.Capote gains the confidence of the accused killers Richard Hickcock played by Mark Pellegrino and especially Perry Smith played by Clifton Collins Jr.  Capote empathized with Smith having had similar childhood experiences of being unwanted and shunned.  Capote however would have no compunction in resorting to manipulation and lying to glean precious information to help him complete his book.Capote in effect sells his soul in seducing and befriending the killers and helping then legally.  In the end can't bring himself to face them at the eve of their execution.  Finally relenting, he witnesses the graphic hanging of Perry Smith. He is shattered but reminded by Keener, as his voice of reason, that he never wanted to really save them and deny himself the precious ending of his book.  We learn that this five year expenditure of Capote's time and effort has dried up his creativity.  He never again wrote another book.

reviewText: The only reason to make a film about someone as controversially repugnant as Truman Capote would be to illuminate his greatest quality- his superb prose writing. At his best, Capote was one of last century's greatest wordsmiths. Instead, the current film, Capote, focuses on the lesser things the man was known for- his showmanship, sensationalism, and homosexuality- although in that last category what is shown is tame and watered down. Now, I'm not saying that a full fledged swordfight between Philip Seymour Hoffman (who plays Capote) and Bruce Greenwood (who plays his lover Jack Dunphy) was necessary, but since the film focuses on the six years Capote was researching and writing his 1965 non-fiction novel In Cold Blood, because of his homoerotic attraction for one of the two killers the book follows, Perry Smith (Clifton Collins, Jr.), it would have illuminated something more about the man. Of course, what creative processes were behind Capote's creation of what he termed `a whole new form of writing'- the `non-fiction novel'- would have been even better.That said, these elements, which are the fault of the screenplay by Dan Futterman, adapted from Gerald Clarke's biography Capote, are the only things that keep this good film from greatness. All the rest of it, including the direction by Bennett Miller, is superb, starting with Hoffman's stab at the icon. This is not a hagiography, and the film makes several wise choices, of which showing Capote's flaws is one. Another excellent choice is to not do a cradle to grave biopic. By focusing only on a few year period it allows us a look at a pivotal point in the character's life. But why, then, not go deeper into the creative processes of the artist? Why not try to provide some insight into why this meek, little man would be so attracted to an amoral thug? Manifestly, there is nothing left to get at with the November 15th, 1959, Holcomb, Kansas murders of the Clutter clan by Smith and Dick Hickock (Mark Pellegrino). As with Leopold and Loeb, before them, and any number of spree killers after them, they are relative ciphers. So, why Capote's need to `understand' them, especially Smith, if not the homo-eroticism? Unless the whole point of the film is to show us Capote as a vampire, waiting for the pair's execution so he could have a good ending for his book.Yet, there was so much more to be mined- Capote's relationship with Jack Dunphy- both as a lover and artist. Considering that Dunphy was not in a league with Capote as a writer would have made their dynamic all the more interesting, as well giving the criminally underrated Greenwood (so good in the cult tv series Nowhere Man and as JFK in the Kevin Costner film Thirteen Days) a chance to show his considerable acting chops in a major role, in an arts house film. Another waste was the whole presence of Capote's childhood friend, Catherine Keener's (Nelle) Harper Lee character, despite her solid portrayal, especially considering her own one hit wonder, To Kill A Mockingbird, was big right at this time.... A final point, though, and that is with the title of the film. Given the wise decision to not go cradle to grave, why such an all-encompassing title? Why not something more specific and germane to what is onscreen? As with much else in the film, such as Hoffman's over-hyped, but solid, performance, it is these little niggles and wrong turns that make so much of what the film does right go wrong enough to just miss being something truly great.

reviewText: I can only provide you with my personal reactions and interpretations of this film.  The intentions of the authors, director, and actors are unknown to me, but what I saw on the screen affected me quite powerfully.  For me, this quiet intenisty is exactly what I most like in film.  One of the things an author must do is see.  To write truthfully an author cannot blink or look away or distract by making sensational effects.  Think of the scene of Capote alone in the funeral parlor with the closed coffins containing the bodies of the family.  Does the author look inside or does his respect and sense of decorum keep the lids closed.  There is not a simple answer or act for anyone of sensitivity.This movie is much like that.  The pictures it shows us are clean, spare, and give us time to look at and into what is going on.  In this movie, facial expressions matter a great deal.  A movement of an eyebrow, a flicker of an emotion that escapes and is then suppressed communicates so much.  Am I reading meaning into the performances?  Maybe.  But the movie gives me the opportunity to see and, well, luxuriate in thought about what is happening inside these people.Of course, the movie is about Capote and he is on the screen nearly constantly.  Philip Seymour Hoffman's performance is so intelligent, so powerfully imaginative, and communicates so continually that I can almost not understand how he accomplished it.  Capote is an immensely complex character.  We see his public bravado and understand its balance with his private insecurities.  However, there is not a simple relationship between the two.  One isn't the cause of the other.Capote is completely able to tell a truth with a lie and then to lie with telling the truth.  We see him genuinely ache for the killer Perry Smith while still manipulating him to get what he wants.  When Capote gets a real and serious lawyer for the killers he may allow himself to feel that he is doing it out of compassion for these men and the fellowship he feels for Smith because of their shared childhood abandonment.  Yet, Capote also knows that he needs to keep them alive long enough to extract their stories and get at the truth so he can write his book.For me, the most amazing scenes in the film are Capote's private exchanges with Smith (and great credit has to be given to Clifton Collins, Jr for his contributions to these scenes).  Capote uses genuine emotion to charismatically pull in Smith.  At other times, he creates a negative emotional pressure that almost forces the emotion within Smith to come out and fill it.  Another time Capote will user superiority and near contempt to manipulate the needy child in Smith.  Yet, in the end, Capote is caught in his own trap.  Capote has to finish his book and for him to do that they murderers need to die.  Yet, Capote's getting them lawyers started them down the path of appeal after appeal and stay after stay.  Finally, Capote has to withdraw any more assistance for Hickock and Smith.  Yet, in abandoning them his own conscience burns and all but destroys him.  When you see his life after "In Cold Blood" one could make the argument that it did him in.Of course, Hoffman's fabulous performance could not exist without other great artists to perform with.  The entire cast of this movie is just wonderful.  Catherine Keener as Harper Lee is perfect as Capote's friend who knows him for what he really is and loves him anyway, but not to the point of self-deception.  Bob Balaban is wonderful and knowing as, William Shawn, the legendary editor of the New Yorker.  He also knows how to manage and manipulate Capote, but is also drawn into this final miserable web of the execution.  Bruce Greenwood's sensitive portrayal of Capote's closest love, Jack Dunphy, allows us to see that as self-involved and capable of hurting others as Capote was, at the extremes he did need another and that was Dunphy.  Chris Cooper and Amy Ryan add so much as the Kansas detective and his wife who are both taken in by Capote's charisma and fame while the detective retrains some distance and skepticism of Capote's ultimate motivation.The rest of the cast is also wonderful and I praise this movie without reservation.The "R" rating comes from some profane language (not a lot) and a brief scene of brutality and blood when the murders are finally recounted.
summary: A magnificent film with amazing performances of great nuance and power

reviewText: Phillip Seymour Hoffman deserved the best actor Oscar he won last spring for his performance in Capote, but Catherine Keener was equally impressive in her interpretation of Capote's long-time friend, the author Harper Lee. This necessarily dreary movie concerns itself with those several years in Capote's celebrated life that revolved around his writing the novel In Cold Blood. Here we see goings-on covered in neither the novel nor film version of In Cold Blood, as Capote befriends Perry Smith, one of two criminals who savagely slew a Kansas family inside its farmhouse. Capote is portrayed here as a troubled, conflicted individual, who both uses Smith to gain information possible only if he has Smith's trust, and also as someone who does seem to genuinely care for Smith, whom he visits during his incarceration on death row. Capote's sexual orientation is not made an issue here and is in fact barely touched upon. Likewise the victimization suffered in the dark past of the psychopathic Smith, which played a significant role in In Cold Blood, is mostly left out. Chris Cooper is sound as the Kansas sheriff who cracks the case of the killings, and one thing wrong with this film is how Capote's near-betrayal of the Sheriff and others who had helped Capote during the formative period of his book is barely mentioned. Truman Capote as portrayed in this film seems a would-be amoral  artist whose conscience won't let him get away clean with all that he does in the name of his art. He'll use people, it's true, but he'll later feel tortured by it. This complexity is intriguing. Capote, the film, might be found too deliberate in its pacing for all levels of patience, and it is certainly bleak, but it is an undertaking in which the performers, writers, and those at work behind the cameras coordinated well and got everything they set out to do exactly, I think, as they wanted it.
summary: Not For The Faint Of Heart

reviewerName: Damian Gunn "The Dark One is I"
reviewText: `Capote' chronicles the efforts of author Truman Capote as he researches for his last completed book.  That last book was the non-fiction novel `In Cold Blood' which delved into the murder of a Kansas family on November 14th 1959.  On that fateful day two men broke into the Clutter home and murdered everyone home.  This event rocked the country, but most of all it drove Truman Capote mad with obsession as he struggled to create the greatest piece of literature ever written.  Truman succeeded in a sense, for `In Cold Blood' made him one of, if not the most famous author in America, but it's not the book itself but the journey to completion that this film presents to us, and it does so masterfully.What makes this film as effective as it is is its attention to detail.  First of all the entire film is shot in very subtle tones.  Everything is quite, from the voices to the eerie score by Mychael Danna; everything is almost in an undertone.  Nothing is overbearing but it all adds to the feel of growing obsession.  The opening scene, where a young girl finds the dead body of her best friend, is a perfect example of what I mean.  The scene is shot with such composure and lucidity that you're almost not sure what you've just seen.  Not many films with this dark a subject attack a project like this with such candor and grace, but director Bennett Miller shows so much caution and delicacy with each approach that you swear he's mastered his talent.  He approaches this film, not with the `in your face' antics that most if not all crime noirs use but he gives us a stripped down raw feel.The score, that constant piano playing is light and background, never breaking the surface and steeling the spotlight but playing perfect companion to the lucid feeling of the film.As Capote (Hoffman) hears first hears of the murders he's immediately intrigued.  He has been waiting for an inspiration, something to sink his creative teeth into and so he decides that an article for the New Yorker on the effect this crime has had on the small Kansas community may be the answer.  He travels along with fellow author and friend Nell Harper Lee (Keener) to Holcomb Kansas to interview the townsfolk, but what he finds is far more than he had anticipated.  Capote, upon meeting the accused, immediately forms a bond with one of the men, Perry Smith (Clifton Collins Jr.) and begins to interview him excessively, furthering his fascination, and, in a sick weird way, his love interest.  Capote goes as far as to get the two men a new lawyer, one that can properly defend them.  This gesture is portrayed to mean one of two things, and the film helps you lean towards one, yet never letting go of the other.  Either Truman wants them around to finish his book or he really has fallen for this killer.  As Truman says himself, it can't be both.Truman's obsession with this case and the men involved starts to put a strain on his relationships, most of all with his boyfriend Jack Dunphy (Bruce Greenwood), but also with Nell as he becomes somewhat self-obsessed and or absorbed.  Truman is painted as a very self-centered man, and this is shown in a few different ways.  One is the fact that whenever other people are around Truman is always shown as the one doing the talking, almost as if he's entertained by the sound of his own voice.  In actuality, while Catherine Keener received a `Best Supporting Actress' nod for her performance (and it was astonishing) she really didn't do too much talking.  Capote completely controlled a conversation.  Another way his self-love is shown is in the way he pays others to compliment him, as if to boost his own self-confidence and make himself desirable to others.  And the final way, or at least the largest display, is the way he could turn any occasion into his occasion, as is seen when he visits the movie premier for Nell's `To Kill a Mockingbird' and he can't `pretend' to be having a good time, not even for her sake.  Her face, her eyes, her final words to him "what did you think of the movie" say everything.The acting in this film, while yes it is what you may call impression acting, is superbly done, notably by Oscar winner Philip Seymour Hoffman who embodied the role of Truman Capote and delivered on every level.  His eyes do a lot of talking in this film, and to me, my favorite scene is another subtle yet powerful one, and one of the scenes I use to prove how powerful this film is in all its calm nature.  The scene where Truman visits the morgue to see the slain is especially prominent, for as he lifts the mothers coffin and looks at her body we can see his soul.  Hoffman, in this scene, with just his eyes portrays a level of understanding and mortification that far surpasses that of `over-acting' and `melodramatics' for if he had made any movements at all, made any sounds or started to cry he would have lost all affect in my opinion, but it was his blank stare and monotone stance that drove home every point we needed.As a whole, this film is exceptionally executed, brilliantly acted, directed and scripted and is, not just a great movie but also an exceptional work of art.  I'd highly recommend the viewing of this docudrama for it opens the eyes and the mind and helps us all see what one man worked so hard for us to understand.  The last few frames are crushing as we watch everything this man wish for come true in shocking realizations that made him make the very statement I chose for my title... "More tears are shed for answered prayers than unanswered ones" and that is such a true statement!
summary: "More tears are shed over answered prayers than unanswered ones."

reviewText: Philip Seymour Hoffman stars as the (in)famous writer Truman Capote (1924-1984) in one of the best films of the year, despite the problems of viewer identification that it might provoke. In researching his "non-fiction novel" In Cold Blood Capote befriended a young man who was convicted and eventually executed for the brutal murder of a Kansas family of four. The portrait of Capote that emerges is of a flamboyant artistic genius whose deeply complex personality reveals itself in decidedly mixed motives. He attracts, repels and fascinates us, all at the same time. In the film Capote befriends the young prisoner Perry Smith for at least four conflicting reasons. Capote was egotistical, vain, narcissistic, condescending and ambitious. Several times he lied to Smith in order to exploit him for selfish, professional purposes in writing his book. When asked if he "esteemed" Smith, Capote replies, "he's a gold mine." Second, Capote's gay lover Jack jealously accused him of falling in love with Smith, which also seems to be true. Third, interviewing Smith evoked powerful memories of his own childhood that resulted in an obsessive act of self-identification and emotional attachment with him: "it's as if we grew up in the same house, but he went out the front door and I went out the back." These memories include exclusion as an outsider, family suicide, alcoholism, and parental abandonment. Finally, Capote genuinely empathized for the young death row inmate, and the film provokes themes of social justice revolving around our penal system and pity for a criminal with a horrible childhood. Smith is not a monster, he insists, and Capote intends his book to "return him to the realm of humanity." Still, Capote chose not to do all that he might have to save Smith; he even wanted Smith to die to supply an ending for his book. When the film ends we learn that In Cold Blood remained an unfinished novel, and that it was the last book that Capote ever wrote, even though he lived another eighteen years. Badly missing in this remarkable film--the slightest mention of the murdered victims and their families. Capote won five Academy Award nominations.

reviewText: Phillip Seymour Hoffman disappears so totally into the role of Truman Capote that you forget you are watching a characterization.  "Capote" is the story of the writer's efforts to chronicle the saga of two killers who murder a prominent small-town Kansas farming family after burglarizing their home in a futile search for money.  On assignment for the New Yorker magazine, Capote is accompanied by childhood friend Harper Lee, who serves as an effective buffer between Capote's effete sophistication (which many find distasteful) and the staid conservatism of 1960's Middle America. Most strikingly, "Capote" portrays the mammoth moral struggle of the writer, who was at once calculating, coldly manipulative and then deeply sympathetic about the plight of the two killers, one of whom he befriends and gradually coaxes to tell his story.  The tremendous fame and wealth from the resulting book "In Cold Blood" did little to offset the enormous emotional and psychological cost of writing it.  Indeed, the film strongly suggests that Capote made a (faustian) bargain with the devil and never really recovered, finally succumbing to alcholism in 1984.  The great supporting cast includes Clifton Collins, Jr.--who personifies small-time desperation as one of the surprisingly articulate killers and Catherine Keener, who simmers as Capote's stoic, long-suffering friend, sidekick and unintentional rival Harper Lee, who herself becomes nearly as famous as Capote for a time after penning "To Kill a Mockingbird."  "Capote" is a serious study--definitely not a "family film."  Director Bennett Miller's brief but arresting images of the violence (murder, execution) prick the heart. Hoffman, who was one of the best things in the 1999 psychological thriller "The Talented Mr. Ripley" (in which he portrayed a loyal, suspicious friend whose skepticism proves fatal) gives one of the most powerful performances in recent memory--it's a masterful tribute to one of the most brilliantly tragic figures in American literary history.

reviewText: Actors break down into two groups for me; excellent and great.  The first group, the excellent actors, bring us "themselves", playing a role perfectly.  Examples might be Robert De Niro, Helen Hunt, Alfre Woodard, even Jack Nicholson.  The second group is very much smaller.  It is composed of great actors who leave themselves behind and become a completely new character, leaving behind the actor and morphing 100% into the role.  We have to look very hard to find the remnants of the actor inside the new character.Phillip Seymour Hoffman, playing Capote, belongs in this second group; not just for his work in Capote but certainly this was the best  vehicle for his magic.  This film is a must see because of his performance.  It is also beautiful filmed, wonderfully written, and intriguing.

reviewText: Capote is a film no writer really deserves. What of Faulkner, Melville or Hemingway? Why Capote? Something clearly intrigues the artistic mind about this little man, who as shown in this film was a little, awful man. He is depicted here as a manipulator and user. He got in with the killers out in Kansas and then pretended to care in order to get their story, in much the same way he had squeezed reticent Marlon Brando for a story about his alcoholic mother. This is a very well made little picture, supremely well-acted by Hoffman, who has been growing year by year into a formidable actor. Just think of that awful little fat boy in "Boogie Nights" and consider how far he has come, giving here one of the great performances of the decade. He is a brave, daring actor, fearless really, and willing to go where few of our handsome leading men are willing to venture. His imitation of Capote is at times spot-on, eerily accurate and yet dynamically singular. The film too has merit. It is a tragedy about a tragedy. It took a while, but clearly Capote decided to kill himself after the hangings in Kansas. One is haunted by the image of Capote pacing the floor of his apartment at the UN Plaza, drinking away his sorrow.

reviewText: This is a very informative movie that has a very personal insight into the man that wrote one of the greatest books of our time. If you are sensitive to a lot of blood and the cold hard truth, this is probably not a movie to put on the top of your watch list. It was an amazing insight into how much of himself Capote put into the research and personal lives of the killers. He was compassionate enough to still see them as human. He tried to treat them with respect to get his story and the facts he wanted, but got too close on a personal level. It appears he never recovered from the ordeal. I think witnessing the actual hanging was just too much. This is a very well done movie if you want a closer look at one of the worst tragedies in our history, but brace yourself, it ain't pretty.
summary: Not a comfortable movie but an eye opening one

reviewText: There's an old joke that goes "I saw "The Buddy Holly Story" and "La Bamba" on a double bill the other night, but I ended up demanding a refund, you wanna know why? THEY BOTH HAD THE SAME ENDING!" (Insert rimshot here). There don't seem to be too many reviewers who have addressed this issue (maybe I'm just showing my age), but anyone who has already seen Richard Brooks' 1967 theatrical treatment of Truman Capote's true crime masterwork is bound to watch "Capote" with more than a little sense of deja vu. Yes, I know we are talking apples and oranges thematically-"In Cold Blood" was a psychological study of the killers, "Capote" is a psycological study of thier biographer. Still, "Capote" begs comparisons (especially when its final shots are basically a frame-by-frame recreation of "In Cold Blood"'s closing scene.) If you can get past that (I guess I couldn't), there are excellent performances here (Phillip Seymour Hoffman's immersion into character is spooky good as always), but they are somewhat tempered by the film's deliberate, glacial pacing. Not that I was expecting car chases, but in my viewing experience, movies that attempt to dissect the writer's mind tend to run into a bit of trouble in the narrative department (witness "Henry and June", "Naked Lunch", "Adaptation", "Barton Fink"). Somewhat absorbing, but not compelling enough for repeated viewings. A guarded recommendation.
summary: A bit spare and a tad familiar

reviewText: All writers---even those of us on the lowest level of the totem pole---subject themselves to moments of intense reflection where the telling of the story from different emotional and rational vantage points simply overwhelms and neutralizes their real world existence.  The aspiration to endow a piece of writing with as much realism as possible equates to countless hours of research where the writer loses himself as he attempts to juxtapose facts from the concrete universe with those rare intermittent lightning strikes of artistic creation that are born in the Valhalla of imagination.  In certain circumstances, the experience plunges the writer into dangerous `heart of darkness' territory where his sentinels of morality shirk their duty and allow their charge to freefall, perhaps irrevocably jeopardizing the very soul desirous of immortality.In the 2005 biopic, "Capote," director Bennett Miller focuses on this process and its repercussions by concentrating on five years in the life of the charismatic and unconventional Truman Capote (Philip Seymour Hoffman) as he germinates and brings to malevolent life a new genre of literature, the quintessential non-fiction true crime epitomized by his brainchild "In Cold Blood" published in 1966.From the opening sequences, we recognize Capote as an electro-magnet of social attention, reigning over raucous Holly Golightly-ish parties with a wavering lit cigarette while enjoying the sound of his own chalk-to-the-blackboard drawl dropping power names that appeared on the Who's Who list of that era with a Southern boy's charm of sounding not only intimate but just plain neighborly.  However, Miller quickly switches from the communal to the cerebral.  Piqued by a short article in the New York Times printed in November 1959, Capote tells New Yorker editor William Shawn (Bob Balaban) that he wishes to write an article exploring the impact of the brutal murder of the well-to-do Clutter family of Holcomb, Kansas on the small mid-western town and its sense of morality.  Accompanied by his research assistant, Nelle Harper Lee (of "To Kill a Mockingbird" fame) (Catherine Keener), the eccentric Capote arrives in middle America, where all his blatant accrued New York verve puts him at odds with the less blaring local color.  Again, his gossipy social skills and his ability to reveal the darker aspects of his rather less than happy childhood allow him to burrow his idiosyncratic way into the homes and hearts of the town's inhabitants that will best help him appropriate the most exacting detail to fashion characters and circumstances for his thrilling and introspective account of the crime.Capote's manipulative skills wax diabolical once Capote sets eyes on Perry Smith (Clifton Collins, Jr), one of the two ex-cons who perpetrated the crime.  Sensing that with his similar background and his need for recognition, Perry may indeed be the living representation of a darker Capote, Capote cannot help but empathizes with him.  He admits to Harper Lee that he feels as if they were both brought up in the same house, only that he, Capote, went out the front door while Perry went out the back.  As Capote is hell-bent to discover what really occurred in the Clutter house on that fall November evening to endow his non-fiction novel with as much gruesome reality as possible, he tries his darnedest to entrap Perry with the accoutrements of friendship---finding him a lawyer for his appeal, spoon-feeding him through a hunger strike and constantly visiting him for the duration of his prison stay.  As time goes on, however, Capote wishes only to finish the book.  The stays of execution that he helped perpetuate gum up his final vision and in spite of his obsession with his subject, he desperately desires only for the state of Kansas to put him and these criminals out of their misery.  The success of `In Cold Blood" speaks for itself, but the toll it takes on Capote is intimated by the film's printed after message noting Capote's descent into alcoholism and his inability to finish another book.On a purely theatrical level, the film's players succeed in bringing an intensely complex psychological study to life without a moment's boredom.  Amazingly, actor Hoffman visibly shrinks as Capote; his huge frame somehow manages to suggest the 5'4" literary dynamo and at the same time implies an aspect of decay not quite actively present during the depicted time period.  Instead, the viewer senses its initial metastasis beneath the surface like an erosion of ethical behavior attributed more blatantly to the visage of the figure in the attic portrait of Dorian Gray.  The lisping baby voice, the affected broken wrist gestures, the Southern drawl, the New York mannerisms all contribute to the illusion Hoffman successfully effectuates.  At first, these seem too theatrical even for Hoffman whose upper crust Freddy Miles in "The Talented Mr. Ripley" albeit true to character bordered on the obnoxious.  That is until the real Capote seems to take possession like a spirit inhabiting a medium.  Hoffman becomes Capote so much so that the viewer has difficulty distinguishing between the actor and subject.Bruce Greenwood, as Capote's long term partner and Catherine Keener as Harper Lee act as our human barometers, aiding us in accessing Capote's true intent while ferociously taking his story to its inevitable conclusion.  We watch them roll their eyes and exchange knowing glances and understand that on some level they perceive Capote's unraveling even before he does.  They exercise patience with Capote's genius and fully comprehend that the obsession that accompanies the hypo-manic personality can only fail on some lesser human plane.  Gravitating towards that dark place holds no sway with their far more contented souls.As Perry, Clifton Collins, Jr. smolders with dual natures both tender and repulsive.  The audience senses his desire for acknowledgement and then cringes when his eyes turn black with suspicion and inner rage for his own misfortunate fate.  The dark intensity of his inner visions acts as a perfect foil for Hoffman's pink and pouty relentlessness.  The two orbit around each other like the blue hot double star Sirius in a macabre dance of eclipsing yearning that drains the audience with almost as much ferocity as its two participants.Bottom line:  Director Bennett Miller constructs a fascinating two-hour study of the process an artist undergoes to give birth to his creation.  Exploring Capote's mind as it unearths the facts necessary to assemble "In Cold Blood" reveals that the selfishness, the desire for perfection, the condoning of deception and the necessity to retreat from the commonplace world that all writers on any level must endure exist in varying degrees in us all and unfortunately take their toll with our dealings in the real life arena of people and circumstance.  Recommended to all.Diana F. Von Behren"reneofc"

reviewText: Great DVD, with good special features.It took me a long time to get around to watching this wonderful movie, and I am truly sorry I waited so song.  CAPOTE is without a doubt one of the best films of 2005. Though I had not previously been a Heath Ledger fan, I found it hard to believe that anyone could out-do his outstanding performance in BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN.  I was wrong.  Philip Seymour Hoffman was astounding as Truman Capote.  BUT its not just his portrayal of Capote that astounded me.  There are probably many actors who could have done as well, after all its easy to portray a 'real' person, especially someone who was in the public eye as much as Capote was.  He's been photographed and filmed so many times, all one has to do is study these films. The reason I believe Hoffman deserved the best actor OSCAR was because of the scene in the movie where Capote says goodbye to the killers.  This scene just absolutely took my breath away, literally.  The emotion and pain on his face was gut-wrenching.  Hoffman himself appeared to have trouble breathing.  I've never seen anything like it in my life!Capote himself was such a flamboyant and charismatic person, that Hoffman had to walk a fine line in order to avoid turning Capote into a caricature of the real man.  In the special features of the DVD, director Bennett Miller tells of his discussion with Hoffman about how he should play the 'goodbye' scene.  Hoffman thought it would be 'too much' for him to break down, and the director gave him leeway to play it as he 'felt' it.  Well, he blew me away.  He walked into that room and his struggle NOT to break down was so REAL that it was hard to watch.  Perry Smith, one of the killers was trying to console HIM, telling him, "Its alright." And Capote sobbing, "I did my best, I did everything I could, I'm sorry.!  Oh my God! I have to buy this movie for this scene alone.

reviewText: This movie tells how Truman Capote wrote "In Cold Blood". It shows the relationship that Capote developed with the killers so that he could get his story. He develops a friendship with Capote and lets him interview the killers.Catherine Keener deserves a Best Supporting Actress nomination for her role as Nelle Harper Lee, who is Capote's long time friend. She assists him in his research and gives him emotional and professional support.The one thing I enjoyed about this movie was that it was very realistic in its portrayal of life in 1959. You really get a strong sense of the era as you watch the movie. People were so much more innocent and naive back then, and it really comes across in the movie. Director Bennett Miller really knows how to give the movie the feel for the times.

reviewText: Not having seen him perform  previously, I was much taken by Hoffman's  portrayal of Truman Capote. He not only captures the externalities of Capote but  provides a moving portrait of a man divided  within by ambition and  a self-identification with his subject. Whether or not that was Capote, I, certainly, cannot tell. Neither can I tell whether it is a portrait consistent with the source materials upon which the script writers and Hoffman, himself, based their interpretations.  All I can say is that I accepted the portrait as a human being and a human being whose exterior actions seem consistent with the internal character meant to be portrayed. Direction,  cinematography (black and white), supporting cast, Kansas settings, combine to convey authenticity, This is a film well-worth seeing, whatever may be ones views on capital punishment, whatever may be one's own conception of the truth of the "confession" and on who was using whom, or perhaps, you will find that each was seeking to manipulate the other and was himself being manipulated.

reviewText: This film is based on a small period of time in the life of American writer Truman Capote. He is a well respected (yet full of himself) writer who becomes fascinated with two men who murder a Kansas farm family of four in cold blood. The effeminate Capote is both entranced and attracted by one of the killers, and he is able to relate to the man's difficult childhood.But Capote uses these men to sell a sensational story. He lies repeatedly to the confined criminals about his progress with the book (he does not represent the men in writing as sympathetically as they may have hoped), and his friend (the venerable writer of "To Kill a Mockingbird" Nelle Harper Lee) rebukes him for caring more about the project and the attention he receives than the prisoners.To be honest, I found the film to be pretty boring, and Capote's accent hard to decipher. I give it 3 stars because the acting is superb, but the storyline is less than mesmerizing.
summary: A Movie about the Making of a Book

reviewText: "In Cold Blood" is one of the most fascinating works of American literature -- a book that blurs the boundaries of fiction and nonfiction.But the writing of the book is almost as fascinating as the events that inspired it, especially since the two became intertwined. This forms the core of "Capote," a fascinating look at the writing project that overwhelmed Truman Capote's life -- and while the movie is quite solid, it's the late Philip Seymour Hoffman who truly shines.Writer Truman Capote (Hoffman) sees a small article in the newspaper, about a family who has been murdered in Kansas, and is immediately inspired to write about it for the New Yorker. Along with his friend Harper Lee (Catherine Keener), he sets out for Kansas and begins interviewing people who knew the Clutter family. They even get to know Alvin Dewey (Chris Cooper), the detective on the case.Then the murderers are caught -- a pair of troubled thugs, Perry Smith (Clifton Collins, Jr.) and Richard "Dick" Hickock (Mark Pellegrino).Suddenly Capote is inspired to take his story far beyond its roots, and his New Yorker story begins to blossom into a full-length book. As he interviews the two men, a warped bond begins to form between Capote and Smith, whom he sees as a kindred spirit.... even though he hasn't revealed how his book will be written. But as the years and legal battles go on, he becomes more determined to finish it at last.The late Philip Seymour Hoffman won an Academy Award for his performance as Truman Capote, and it isn't hard to see why. He seems to slip into Capote's skin -- his looks, his high nasal voice, his fey mannerisms -- but he also fills the cracks with lots of genuine emotion. His Capote is both vulnerable and manipulative -- and thankfully, director Bennett Miller is intelligent enough to realize that neither eclipses the other.On one hand, Capote seems to feel a true connection to Perry, as if they are two sides of the same coin -- in one scene, he plaintively tells Harper Lee that he and Perry came from the same house, and that he went "out the front door" while Perry was forced to leave via "the back." But the movie doesn't shy away from the suggestion that Capote manipulated the convicted men to get the book he wanted, although the extent is left ambiguous.And as the movie winds on, Hoffman's Capote seems to be slowly crumbling under the weight of his magnificent book that he's producing, as if it's vampirically sucking out his vital juices. At the end, he's emotionally and creatively spent, adrift, left only with the reflections of his darker self.As a recounting of "what happened," the film is actually pretty close to the reality of what happened -- it follows Capote closely as he winds his way through the Kansas town, with Harper paving the way before his feet. Miller mostly depends on Hoffman for atmosphere, letting him fill the scenes with emotion or intensity -- but he brings a tautness to phone calls, a darkness in the executions, and a sense of barely-restrained violence when the convicts are onscreen.The other actors are all pretty good, although they are effectively window dressing for Hoffman -- Catherine Keener is the only one who truly rises above the herd, depicting Lee as a sharp, smart, incisive woman whom Capote leans on."Capote" is one of those movies that is elevated to brilliance by the presence of a truly great actor -- and the director's delicate, nuanced touch with Capote's psyche doesn't hurt either.
summary: ... while I went out the front.

reviewText: ...Seymour Hoffman that is, this man truly deserved his Oscar.  I've long admired his fine acting, reminds me of Paul Giametti who's another immensely talented yet not terribly well-publicized actor because he isn't very photogenic and would hardly qualify for male-bimbo status like a Tom Cruise nor does he have the generic "all-American" mainstream appeal of a Harrison Ford or Kevin Costner.  Both excel at playing slightly (or not so slightly) unhinged characters.In this film, Hoffman does a phenomenal job on Truman Capote---especially in the scene just before the execution at the end of the film.  His face just flows so effortlessly from one emotion and mood to the next, expresses a combination of conflicting emotions perfectly.Catherine Keener is another highly talented and under-recognized actress who shines in this film, here she actually plays a relatively normal straight-laced woman for a change rather than her usual shrewish characters.  Chris Cooper and Clifford Collins round out the flawless cast.  The cinematography and editing are done well---this film like Capote's writing has a both spare/austere and sensuous quality which keeps your attention riveted.  Very fast 2 hours.Best of all is the lack of any sugarcoating on the simple fact that for Capote to get the story that he wanted to write, he had to bribe, manipulate, and lie between his teeth to his subject.  There is also no sugarcoating the fact that aside from being a ruthless journalist in doing his job, Capote was also a classic self-absorbed narcissist driven by a hunger for recognition and fame.  All the same, like his novel's portrayal of these Kansas killers, Capote is shown to be neither a devil nor a saint but simply what he is---human.  Therein lies the film's genius.

reviewText: Although he was a celebrated author, I have to admit my initial familiarity with Truman Capote came from his frequent appearances during the 1970's on "The Tonight Show" with Johnny Carson, as well as his silly appearance as duplicitous millionaire Lionel Twain in Neil Simon's 1978 "Murder by Death". Capote's effete manner and often patronizing comments (e.g., he opined that all actors were basically stupid) made such a strong impression on me that it was not until much later that I realized he wrote such gems such as "Breakfast at Tiffany's", "The Grass Harp", "The Thanksgiving Visitor", and of course, his seemingly atypical masterwork, "In Cold Blood". It is the intensive research and writing of this latter work, a self-proclaimed "non-fiction novel" published to great acclaim in 1965, which is the basis of this well-crafted though sometimes slowly paced movie.For those who have not read "In Cold Blood" or seen the stark 1967 film adaptation directed by Richard Brooks, the true-life story focuses on Perry Smith and Dick Hickock, a pair of drifters who break into the home of a Kansas farm family in November 1959 based on a rumor that they had $10,000 stashed away. Upon discovering that the family had no money on hand, Smith and Hickock systematically killed the four members of the family.  First-time director Bennett Miller recreates much of the book's plot, including the gory crime, within the context of the movie. On a broader level, this film focuses on Capote's journey of over four years in chronicling the story until the inevitable ending, and in the meantime getting to know the killers intimately, especially the more enigmatic Smith. Actor Dan Futterman, familiar from his guest turns on "Will and Grace" and "Sex in the City", has written a delicately balanced screenplay that highlights the contradictory forces with which Capote was grappling in getting his story on paper.Although Miller's direction and Futterman's script are both strong for rookie efforts, the key to the film's effectiveness lies in the performances. In a startling transformation, Philip Seymour Hoffman inhabits Capote from the most subtle mannerism to his inner soul. Always a fine character actor, Hoffman brings his dead-on impersonation to a level of consciousness that exudes just the right shadings of narcissism, vulnerability and self-destruction. From the snippets of Capote regaling cocktail party guests in Manhattan with his stories to his useless wardrobe name-dropping in Kansas, there is no question in Hoffman's performance that Capote is a man in love with himself. As author Harper Lee, Capote's closest confidante and research partner on the killings, the always watchable Catherine Keener unaffectedly presents the sturdiness of her plain-spoken character, and their close, painfully honest relationship is believable.The other striking performance is provided by Clifton Collins Jr., who brings out the alternating coldness and vulnerability in Smith, especially as his character naively and desperately comes to regard Capote as his friend. The prison cell scenes between Hoffman and Collins have an intriguing, disturbing charge that subconsciously seems to point to the homoerotic nature of their relationship. Smaller roles are filled expertly - Chris Cooper in familiar territory as Sheriff Alvin Dewey and Bruce Greenwood as Capote's patient lover, author Jack Dunphy - though their scenes feel truncated compared to the rest of the story. In fact, the film feels rushed toward the end as Capote is obviously deeply affected by the events and his own culpability in the killers' fate. I only wish there was a greater sense of a denouement to the film, but regardless, the film is certainly worth seeing for Hoffman's masterful performance.
summary: Startling Hoffman Performance Emblazons Intense Treatment of Capote's Life-Changing Episode

reviewText: This movie incorporates just about every aspect a great movie should have:  tremendous acting, directing, and script.  The director, Bennett Clarke, has done wonderfully to evoke the period (late 1950s- early 1960s), the place (rural Kansas, "hip" literati Brooklyn) and the personages from Capote (Philip Seymour Hoffman) to Perry Smith (Clifton Collins Jr.).  The script is spot on, highlighting as if presciently precisely those words and prompting just those actions in the actors to make them completely convincing.  Finally, most superlatively, the acting.  This movie is about acting:  Catherine Keener is a brilliantly understated (Nell) Harper Lee;  Chris Cooper equally so as sheriff Alvin Dewey.  The killers, Mark Pellegrino and Clifton Collins Jr. deftly portray the line walked between sanity and insanity.  It is of course Philip Seymour Hoffman's movie and it is his acting that makes this movie the best of its type.  Hoffman's performance was so good that he deserves the oscar for next year as best actor, no matter who his competition is.  Really, an amazing (albeit depressing) performance.  Four stars only for the movie's abrupt ending:  an epilogue (not written) was needed.

reviewText: After watching this film, it is very easy to see why this movie is so praised. reviewText: A couple things from late 1959 seem to stick in my mind. One was the brutal murder of an entire family in western Kansas. That one created real shock waves in that we lived in Boulder, Colorado. which was only a couple hundred miles away and the killers remained free for a while. A second thing was that I had enrolled in graduate school far away in Seattle. I knew no one, had no friends and nothing to do other than school work. It was one of those periods in my life when I lost myself in reading. One of my favored authors was Truman Capote and I read a couple of his books. "Breakfast at Tiffany's" and "Other Voices, Other Rooms" come to mind. I remember being startled when I learned of Capote going to Kansas to research the situation in order to white a book about the grisly crime and the convicted killers. It seemed totally out of character and I couldn't imagine what type of book would come out of this situation. Well, the resulting book was the very highly acclaimed "In Cold Blood" and Capote was informally crowned America's greatest living author.I never got around to reading "In Cold Blood" as I was then deeply into my latter days of graduate school and the early years of my career as a professor. Likewise, when the movie "Capote" came out, I just wasn't into going to movies. Lately, my wife and I have been watching movies late at night on DVDs. So, I was scratching through the ultra-bargain DVD shelf in a Ross store and there was the "Capote" DVD and I snapped it up immediately. Strangely, my wife refused to watch it in that she didn't like the idea of a family getting murdered. I tried to explain, but it was no use. I watched it last night while she was at a baby shower. The movie was simply outstanding!Several things stand out about the movie "Capote." One was the directing and the magnificent capturing of the stark beauty of western Kansas and the depiction of the people. Outstanding! Secondly, I've seen Truman Capote on talk shows many times and, of course, he's a completely unique and easily recognized personality. Well, Philip Seymour Hoffman did an absolutely stunning job of portraying Capote in the movie. There were times when he was so close in looks and voice, that I'd almost swear that it actually was Capote. Surely, this was acting at it's finest!The story of "Capote" unfolded in a somewhat grim documentary style, but it fit the situation perfectly and I felt no lapse of attention at any point in the movie. All acting was excellent! The story was completely believable and made for compelling viewing. The movie left me with deep emotional feelings, even for the hapless killers. The movie is a stunning portrait of of a tragic event and it's aftermath.Gary Peterson

reviewText: CAPOTE is a great movie.  Let that be said at the beginning of this review.  The superb screenplay by Dan Futterman based on the book by Gerald Clarke in turn based on that part of the  life of Truman Capote when he was obsessed with writing his final and finest novel 'In Cold Blood', and the extraordinary directing by Bennett Miller who influenced a fine production crew and coaxed brilliant performances from his cast is all a well established fact.  That all of this could be brought together in the featurettes that accompany the film on the DVD release is an example of just how fine additive commentaries can be. This is not only a superb film; it is also an equally superb DVD package.Philip Seymour Hoffman as the idiosyncratic author Truman Capote probes the psyche of this strange but gifted writer from his first newspaper clipping of the November 15, 1959 brutal murders of the Clutter family in Holbrook through his immersion in the tiny Kansas town accompanied by his friend and fellow writer Harper Lee (Catherine Keener) absorbing the atmosphere where such a deed could happen, ingratiating himself with investigator Alvin Dewey (Chris Cooper) and his wife Marie (Amy Ryan) to gain access to information that will eventually result in material for his projected book.  He becomes obsessed with the murderers Perry Smith (Clifton Collins, Jr.) and Richard Hickock (Mark Pellegrino), connecting with Smith in particular on a very basic level and providing the men with lawyers to appeal their conviction for a long enough time to eventually hear the truth of the night of grisly mayhem that fascinates Capote so. The story ends with the execution of Smith and Hickock in 1965, an occasion that further bewilders the now fragile mind of Capote as he gains the end to his story while simultaneously watching the loved Smith dangle from the scaffold in death.  Each actor is exceptional here: Hoffman does indeed deserve his Oscar for a brilliant portrayal.But it is the aftermath that brings even more poignancy to the film.  Hearing Bennett, Clarke, and Futterman discuss the origin of the cinematic idea blends naturally with the production crews' commentary about the choice of Winnipeg, Canada as the location to depict Kansas, the thorough preparation of the design and costuming and color palette and camera techniques, and then the comments by four of the main actors (Hoffman, Keener, Cooper, and Collins) illuminate not only the characters they depicted in the film but also the dynamics of entering into this strange world of bleak winter murder.  The effect of the featurettes is staggering and makes the viewer want to immediately replay the entire movie.This DVD package should serve as the template for future releases: the disc in its entirety is an art form that has few peers.  Highly Recommended. Grady Harp, March 06
summary: The DVD Package Makes CAPOTE Even More Gripping

reviewText: Capote is an extraordinary film. I considered giving it four stars seeing the average amazon rating but no, in order for me to right a faithful description of this movie, I must mention..Capote contains some beautiful sets. It's not an expensive film, I liked how the character Capote is introduced, also liked how he speaks and his character definition and how precisely the director has depicted his state of mind. In the end, I thought the film seemed a tad too realistic and thus, looked dull. However, it is what is meant to be, a documentary'ish depiction of a columnist/author who decided to write a book on two killers. Later,he is stuck between going ahead and printing his book (In Cold Blood) or fighting for the cause of the two convicts. He could have gone either way.Capote's character isnt overtly amusing, isnt too funny, it's his human side that will make you chuckle/semi grin now and then. I thought the depiction of 1959 to mid 1960's was simply superb considering it's a low budget venture.SEMI SPOILER ALTERT/WHAT I LIKED -I liked the scene in the film where Capote refuses to take Lee's phone call. I liked how he acknowledges a man's remark on the introductory speech of his book and later addresses him as his father.Overall, I felt Capote's character is a tad boring. I understand it's a real story and all, but in the end it seems a bit too realistic for a movie to stand.The film lacked irony, magical moments, whoa inducing twists or sequences, a consistent piano sound in the theme and a character that would be very likeable.Chris Cooper's role is rather yawn inducing. However, I MUST SAY, Capote is one of the most daring thin edged directed movies I have ever seen. There is very very little room for error and since I am a big time movie enthusiast(movie person too) I felt it somewhat wins it's battle.However, I got the message of the film, the facts of it, however, Where do I go from there?Possibly one of the best 3star films you'll ever see. Definitely worth watching for those who know what it's about.

reviewText: Hoffman's performance is perfect. The problem with the movie IMO is Clifton Collins as Perry Smith. This was the role played by a very young Robert Blake in 1967 in the very good Richard Brooks film. Blake captures the complexity of this extremely complicated murderer - for instance, the rage simmering just below the I-want-to-impress-you-with-my-vocabulary surface. Collins doesn't do nearly as well, his performance is flat, sort of wilted, we don't see that glimmer of Satan that Blake was able to produce. (If I remember correctly, Blake got way, way into the role, to the point where he became self-destructive.) Perry Smith is one of the biggest acting challenges of modern movies. In "Capote" it's a huge role. The conversations between him and Capote in the jail cell are the core of the film. Too often they're a bit boring; Hoffman holds up his end but we don't find ourselves all that interested in Collins. But, with all of that said, the film is worth seeing for Hoffman's work.
summary: OK - See It for Hoffman's Performance

reviewText: In the first years of the past Century the figures of Mallarme, Verlaine and Baudelaire represented in France one step ahead in many fronts. They represented the anguish, the febrile despair and expressed with absolute conviction their sarcastic and dark opinions about the future to come. Those diviner voices have always resulted unpleasant for a the most of people, because they are considered something like the uninvited guest, the unblessed angels, the lucidity of the conscious in its most cruel nakedness.Truman Capote was one of these voices. His naturalness at the moment to express awful truths deserved to him the expected results. But he was not the only on. You should add this list names of the height of Sinclair Lewis, Faulkner, Steinbeck, Hemingway, Steinbeck, Alan Ginsberg and Kerouac.This film portraits with admirable crudeness, those years in which the phantoms that still nestled in the mind of many people and permeated behaviors and attitudes of intransigence and repression as natural response to the recent wounds of the WW2.You should notice a similar phenomena happened in Germany; two names are enough to prove it: Gunther Grass and Peter Handke.It would be worthy to remark the fact the 2006 Academy Awards turned around the past (Brokeback mountain, Good night and good luck, Capote and Munich) indicate a visible process of cathartic depuration and an obvious need to analyze the traces of a recent past to realize many hidden aspects of the collective unconscious.Philip Seymour Hoffman has given securely the role of his lifetime. Regarding he is a young and talented actor, something inside me tells me he reached that genius trait, this sublime peak achieved for others actors. For instance George C. Scott with Patton, Anthony Hopkins with The silence of the lambs, Clift Robertson with Charly, Ben Kingsley with Gandhi, Broderick Crawford with All the king's men, Peter O'Toole with Lawrence of Arabia, or Jack Nicholson with One flew over the cuckoo' s nest. That performance level in which you may state he achieved the state of art and more than an actor he became a model.An absolute modern classic.
summary: A devastating testimonial of a recent Age!

reviewText: Many people, especially those old enough to remember when the book In Cold Blood came out, know about the hoopla caused by Capote's best known work.  They and many others afterwards have heard about Capote's work on the book, have seen the movie made several years ago, and may even remember that he wrote almost nothing after.  Seeing the process, however, is very different.  This movie drives home the machinations -- the possible heartlessness -- that went into the research and publication and they are almost too much to bear.The movie itself is starkly done.  The dialog is sparse.  Yet, we see into the heart and soul of the writer and killer who so fascinated Capote, even if only for a moment.  Viewers can't take their eyes away from the friendship that grows between the two, until Perry is cut off at the knees, being left to flounder in his own guilt and isolation.  It's difficult not to wonder if Capote's tears are genuine; yet at the same time it is equally difficult not to feel a touch of compassion for him.It is agreed by many literary experts that In Cold Blood changed certain aspects of writing forever.  The subject alone is chilling.  Those involved, directly or indirectly, never forgot any detail.  There are two characters here who demonstrate the thin line between genius and madness.  The quiet telling of that story makes the impact even more powerful.

reviewerName: Ingrid Heyn "No man is an Iland, intire of it...
reviewText: The most terrifying thing about the film "Capote", which only began screening recently here in Australia, is that the title of "monster" is lifted to reveal the whole complex network of influences which play a part in human decisions.Why do killers kill? Many killers kill not because they consider themselves to be killers, but kill because their lives have led them to an increasing lack of respect for life, for the rights of other human beings to live unmolested and unharmed, for the necessity of any violent tendencies within oneself to be disciplined, and perhaps most importantly... for one not to confuse one's own feelings (considering oneself "sympathetic" and "sensitive") with genuine empathy, the genuine love for mankind that makes John Donne's famous sonnet with the oft-quoted phrase "No man is an island, entire unto himself" so stunningly apposite and powerfully true.The two killers whose acts brought murder into a quiet Kansas town became the raison d'tre for Truman Capote's new work. Previously, his writing had included lighter pieces as "Breakfast at Tiffany's" - which is not exactly lacking in darker emotions and complexity, but is more geared towards a serio-romantic tradition. There was nothing romantic in the new book Truman Capote had in mind... the now-famous "In Cold Blood".This film is about the creation of that book and the nature and character of Truman Capote, increasingly revealed throughout the course of the film as the book and the interviews its writing entailed become all-consuming to him.Capote himself is depicted with brutal honesty - his self-centredness, his egocentric desire to be the centre of attention, his callousness in the face of the desperation desire to live, and to be understood, on the part of the two killers, his uninterest even in the success of his friend Harper Lee in the wake of the publishing of "To Kill A Mockingbird", and his almost unbelievably expressed desire to have "it" over with ("it" being the execution of the two killers).The complexity of this film is remarkably well done. It's beautifully paced, subtle and powerful - I note that some reviewers are dissatisfied with the film on the basis of its being too slow and too thoughtful, too lost in the moment. Perhaps to some viewers, accustomed to films in which hectic car chases follow one upon the other, and accustomed to reading the novels of Matthew Reilly, the film truly MAY be too slow for their liking. I can only say it worked beautifully for me. I was gripped by the story and its chilling unfolding from beginning to end.Capote's relationship with one of the killers - Perry Smith - is especially important. He is accused by his lover Jack of being in love with Perry, but also of using him. Capote is unable to grasp how both of these things could be true - but in the sense of "love" as understood by Capote's set, there is no difficulty.Perry Smith is a handsome young man, articulate, apparently sensitive, deeply aware of how he's perceived by others, craving respect and understanding. His diaries reveal that he fantasised about being admired by others - note his "If called upon to make a speech" entry. The murders of the father, mother, son and daughter were not committed out of hatred, desperation, necessity... and this is chilling. The line that divides us from monstrous deeds can be crossed at any moment by a decision or a reaction that takes less than the blink of an eye. And it is in Perry Smith's life that the film shows hints of what led to the murders - bit by bit, Perry Smith descended into increasingly antisocial activity, until finally, the man he'd tied up and was badgering for information on money in the house looked at him with terror. Looked at him with terror... and Perry Smith cut his throat.There WAS no reason. The internal callousness of this young man, who in many ways was sensitive and thoughtful, simply led to a knee-jerk act - and having committed the first murder, Perry Smith followed through with the other three murders almost as though in a trance.Was he mentally ill? No. Had he been driven to these murders? No. Did he gain anything by murdering? No. There is such a thin wall between acceptable behaviour and monstrous behaviour - and even the committer of the deed cannot explain why he did what he did. He looks at himself and sees, not a murderer, but a man tormented by having DONE something he cannot understand.Drawn into an attraction towards Perry Smith, and yet separate from Smith's emotions by his own insulating case of egocentricity, Capote clearly extracted as much information from the prisoner as he could. It is based upon this intimate understanding that the true chills of the "In Cold Blood" title of the book makes its most powerful appeal.But in this film "Capote", the coldness is uncannily apt with respect to Capote's own behaviour and emotions. He desperately wishes for the execution to be over, so that at last he can finish his book. The book MUST end with the finality of that execution - every stay of execution is like a deliberate affront to him, a deliberate attempt to torment him. His masterpiece must be published - this is the pivotal thought in Capote's mind.The cinematography is wonderfully done in this film. The directing - magnificent. I loved the pace of the film. And the acting... is so good that one forgets one is watching actors, not the real people.Having seen the film, I'm ordering the DVD. I can't say it's a "feel good" film - I can say it is powerful and thought-provoking, and the friend with whom I saw the film and I have found it richly working in our minds so that we have discussed it in depth.Very highly recommended.
summary: The coldness of the soul... the chill of the fait accompli.

reviewText: I remember reading "In Cold Blood" and finding it riveting. I read it all in about one sitting many years ago.  What I didn't realize when I read it, and seeing the movies made of it in between, was how much Capote identified with Perry Smith.  This revelation makes the movie worth watching in itself.  Capote says, "I feel like Perry and I grew up in the same house, he walked out the back door, and I walked out the front."  I think the identification is what made the book so powerful.  Capote began the category of writing now known I guess as Creative Non-Fiction, but what still floors me, is how much he gave of himself in creating the masterpiece.Capote did become a washout insidiously after the completion of the book.  What higher price can one pay for creating a great work of art?  It seems to me, that the creative genius in him was hung with Perry Smith.Incredible movie, a must see, I think.  I can't wait to buy it, and read the book again.The movie is not for everyone, it deals with grim material.  Although, there were many strong performances, I doubt the Oscars will give it any recognition.  After all, the commercialization of Capote is what killed him too.
summary: Gripping but sad story all around.

reviewText: I caught a sneak preview of Capote at the ArcLight earlier this evening and I have to say: Dammmmnnnnnn!Capote is based on the true story of how Truman Capote, one of America's legendary writers, came to write his masterpiece non-fiction, In Cold Blood--an account on a mass murder that took place in Kansas City on November 15, 1959. The film concentrates on Capote's interaction with the lead killer through the meetings he managed to arrange for them in jail. It explorers how researching the murder affected Capote and changed him forever.The film is remarkable! It captures the late '50s and early '60s impeccably with flawless set dressing and imposed film grain. Capote's interesting life was touched upon with certain aspects highlighted such as his friendship with Harper Lee--author of literary classic To Kill a Mockingbird--and his effiminacy.Philip Seymor Huffman should win an Oscar for his outstanding performance as Truman Capote. His accent, posture, gestures and most subtle inflections were perfection. He definitely delivered the best performance by an actor in a leading role this year thus far.Everyone should see this film! It's a terrific story with stellar performances. It doesn't get better than this.
