reviewerName: I. Sondel "I. Sondel - lover of the arts"
reviewText: Nominated for five Academy Awards (including Best Picture, Director and Screenplay) "Capote" was my favorite film of 2005.  I thoroughly believe that in other, less talented hands, this film would have been a mess.  Director Bennett Miller has made a beautiful film with uniformly brilliant performances.  Without once drifting into gross caricature Philip Seymour Hoffman (who won the Oscar for his performance) did the impossible by bringing Capote the person and not Capote the persona to life.  Catherine Keener (an Oscar nominee for her work here) plays Nell Harper Lee with great understatement.  Chris Cooper as investigator Alvin Dewey, Clifton Collins Jr as murderer Perry Smith and Bruce Greenwood as Capote's longtime companion Jack Dunphy, are equally effective in challenging roles."Capote" isn't easy.  This is not a standard Hollywood bio-pic.  It was never the intention of screenwriter Dan Futterman to adapt Gerald Clarke's exhaustive biography of Capote in its entirety, but rather to bring to the screen those chapters dealing with the author's life at the time he was compoing his true-crime masterpiece "In Cold Blood."Much fuss mas been made over the fact that Truman used Perry Smith and Dick Hickock in an exploitive way; that he "needed" them alive only long enough to reveal their side of things, and then executed in order to finish his book.  I'm not totally convinced that the author's actions were so cold or calculated.  I know from what I've read (and now seen) that Capote was truly conflicted about his obligation to these men.  He did pay for their first appeal.  Still, did he do all that he could to see that thier death sentence was commuted?  Was he actually honor bound to do more on their behalf?  Let us not forget the family of four who lay dead in that farm house - they were shown no mercy, given no appeals and certainly no stay of execution.  These are the issues the film brilliantly explores.  In the end "Capote" presents one of the most acutely realized and compelling examinations of personal and professional ethics in relation to the creative process, and the often corrupting influence the persuit of greatness can have on the artist.  This is a must see film.
summary: Best Film of 2005 - according to me.

reviewText: I always find it fascinating when two movies about the same topic come out very closely together. This has happened too many times for it to be coincidence. We had Dead Man on Campus vs. The Curve. Dangerous Liaisons vs. Valmont. Elizabeth vs. Shakespeare in Love. The Thin Red Line vs. Saving Private Ryan. Antz vs. A Bug's Life, Finding Nemo vs. A Shark's Tale Etc, etc. And now we have Capote vs. Infamous. Not just two movies with similar topics, but two movies that chronicle the exact same period of time about the exact same period of people, namely Truman Capote and the Kansas-family killers.ScorecardBetter at being Truman Capote---Philip Seymour Hoffman. Toby Jones had the advantage of looking more like Capote, and being more on point with Capote's mannerisms, but his performance comes off as mimicry. Hoffman doesn't mimic, he acts. Plus, he gets points for degree of difficulty. He doesn't look like Capote at all, but he pulls it off. He even manages to make Capote somewhat sexy.Better acting from the rest of the cast---Capote. With the exception of Sandra Bullock as Harper Lee, the rest of the Infamous cast is outshined by Capote's cast. Infamous has a lot of big names, but their parts are so minimal that it's almost a waste.Better Love story---Capote. The love story is a little too subtle, but the interaction between Capote's Truman and Smith works really well. Perry Smith is portrayed with more gentility, and it becomes believable Truman could have fell for him. Daniel Craig plays Perry Smith like a schizophrenic who at one point gags and threatens to rape Capote. That's not how you fall in love. The love angle is not believable at all in Infamous.Better script---Capote. The writing is tighter and more focused while Infamous's writing is a little jerky. We spend a little too much time with Truman's friends. And the interview style of the movie seems like a crutch. Capote was able to tell its story through action while Infamous needs the characters breaking the flow of the movie to tell the audience what's going on.Better movie---Capote. It is bleak but better directed, better acted, and better executed. Infamous has lighter and funnier moments, but it can at times come off as frivolous.I just wish Capote hadn't made Truman seem so evil. They play him entirely too ruthless and manipulative. And as a result, we are forced to sympathize with murderers of 4 innocent people.In situations like this, it becomes obvious that the quicker one to the punch gets rewarded. Capote was released first; it got the attention; and it got the Oscar. Infamous is now just a footnote to Capote's page. But I like and enjoy both films; and maybe they should act as companion pieces. Glue them together, and maybe you'll get one accurate picture of Truman Capote.

reviewText: How Philip Seymour Hoffman, who I read somewhere is 6'2", thoroughly becomes the elfin Truman Capote is one of the greater acting mysteries of the year, but he does and as a result Capote is a terrific movie in every frame. Beginning with the Clutter family murders in rural Kansas and covering Capote's struggles to write In Cold Blood, the movie also has superb acting by Catherine Keener (last seen bringing sanity to the world of middle-aged male stupidity in 40 Year Old Virgin), the always estimable Chris Columbus, and Clifton Collins as Perry Smith, one of the killers and in this movie, the only one that matters. Five stars too to the director and cinematographer who superbly contrast the bleak winter open space of the Kansas prairie and the confining closeness of the jail scenes with Capote and one of the killers, Perry Smith. As good as he is in capturing Capote physically, Hoffman does even better with his psychological make-up. Charming, manipulative, and -- gradually -- in love with Smith, Capote is torn between wanting to save Smith's life and knowing he needs him dead for his book to have the ending it requires. One of the film's nicer twists is how this user also becomes the used -- meeting his match in Smith.There may be better movies than Capote in 2005, but they will surely be few in number, and frankly now, in mid-December, it's only rival to my mind is Brokeback Mountain.

reviewText: Rated "R". Running Time: 1 hour, 54 mins.Truman Capote was an author of many short stories, novels, plays and non-fiction work. Known forBreakfast at Tiffany's: A Short Novel and Three Stories (Modern Library). He wrote for The New Yorker Magazine and was an actor inMurder By Death(1976) andAnnie Hall(1977).This movie begins on the day of November 14, 1959 when a family of four were murdered in their house in a small town in Kansas.After seeing the article about the crime in the newspaper, author Truman Capote decides to write about the crime and how it effected the small town of Holcomb, Texas.With his research partner, Harper Lee (Catherine Keener), Truman goes to the small town to see the scene of the crime and talk with the girl, Laura (Allie Mikkelson), who found the body of her best friend.After the two murderers, Dick Hickock (Mark Pellegrino) and Perry Smith (Clifton Collins Jr.) are caught, Capote gets a chance to talk with Perry in a cell and then even attends the trial.Over the course of four years, Capote becomes friends with Perry Smith and visits him in prison. He tells the murderers he will help get them a lawyer. Unbeknownst to Perry Smith, Capote is trying to get answers out of him for his work.With all the material Capote has, he has decided to write a book,In Cold Blood (Modern Library), but because he was waiting for Perry Smith to finally open up and talk about the murders and wanting an ending of this case, the book was not published until 1966. The book was later adapted in the movie,In Cold Blood(1967) starring Scott Wilson and Robert Blake.Also in the cast: Bruce Greenwood, Amy Ryan, Chris Cooper, Kelci Stephenson, Craig Archibald, Bronwen Coleman, Kate Shindle, David Wilson Barnes, Michael J. Burg, Bob Balaban.I am just amazed by the performance of Philip Seymour Hoffman. From the first time I saw him inTwister [Blu-ray] (1986), a character he played that was hog-wild rowdy, to someone as vulnerable as Truman Capote.Philip Seymour Hoffman won the Golden Globe Award and Academy Award for Best Actor in 2006.The movie was also nominated for an Academy Award for Best Picture, Supporting Actress- Catherine Keener, Best Screenplay.Option of Languages: English, French.Option of Subtitles: English, French, Spanish, Portuguese, Bahasa, Cantonese, Mandarin, Korean, Thai.Audio Commentary #1 with Philip Seymour Hoffman and Bennett Miller.Audio Commentary #2 with Bennett Miller and Adam Kimmel.3 Featurettes.Another film about Truman Capote,Infamousstarring Toby Jones with Daniel Craig (before "James Bond") as "Perry Smith" was released October 13, 2006.
summary: The writer who got close to the story.

reviewText: Movie audiences have always loved movies about movies.  And even more so, movies about very popular movies.  Capote is a movie about the writing of a book that became a very popular movie.  The critics certainly loved Phillip Seymour Hoffman's performance as the tortured novelist and the movie Capote; it's just a question of time before we know how popular this film turns out to be.  As far as I am concerned, Capote is the first major DVD release of 2006.In Cold Blood has long been considered one of the most realistic crime dramas ever filmed, and it's considered a high-point of 1960's cinema, mostly for it's documentary style.  In the film Capote, Philip Seymour Hoffman as Capote mentions that In Cold Blood represented a new type of literary accomplishment, a work based on fact presented in the style of narrative fiction.  Capote himself said that the book was meant to re-define non-fiction, and in fact, it did.  Many writers have since copied the style pioneered by Capote in the book In Cold Blood.The film tells the story of the writing of the book, and how it led to Capote's artistic downfall, despite its overwhelming success.  The film makes it clear that Capote was emotionally involved with one of the killers, but not enough to prevent himself from lying and manipulating the condemned and doomed men to get what he wanted.  The film also clearly details the cold emotionless manner in which Capote is able to divorce himself from his feelings and his conscience in order to develop his book, deceiving the killers into believing that their cooperation would somehow lead to their lives being spared, if not their actual exoneration.  In the process, Capote loses track of his own moral compass, yet was profoundly affected by his intense involvement with the two killers.  In order to gain their trust, Capote had to develop a friendship with the killers, and in fact, his friendship Perry Smith (played by Clifton Collins Jr.) borders on obsession.  We are never quite sure throughout the film exactly what is going on inside Capote's head; at times his interest in the killer's welfare appears quite genuine, at other points it appears that he is using them solely for the sake of getting a good book out of it.  Whatever his precise feelings, he suffered for his involvement - a post script to the film reminds us that In Cold Blood was the last piece of work that Capote ever finished.  Following the books completion, he began a downhill progression into alcohol addiction that he never overcame.  The film does not dwell on Capote's sexuality; although his male partner is included in several scenes, their relationship is never explored or physically represented, and his homosexuality is given a matter-of-fact but unobtrusive handling.Some of the scenes lifted from those in the original film In Cold Blood are done so well that, aside from the fact that the original was filmed in black and white, you can scarcely tell the difference.  The scene towards the end when the killers are finally executed so closely resembles the original film that you almost think it was lifted directly from it.On the whole, the film is dramatically satisfying and extremely entertaining.  Coupled with the extraordinary performance of Philip Seymour Hoffman, it emerges as a near perfect motion picture.

reviewText: Selecting the final segment in the life of author Truman Capote, the film "Capote", delves into the inner and certainly troubled soul of the American Novelist. The film itself, is a somber reflection of the price Capote paid to write what appears to be his most poignant work. The introduction of the book and the movie itself invites the audience into the real life drama of the Kansas family who were brutally murdered by two killers named Richard Hickock (Mark Pellegrino) and Perry Smith (Clifton Collins) in 1963. Along the way, one observes how adroitly, the writer is able to weave his tapestry between truth and fiction to achieve his ultimate goal. With the help of an assortment of great actors, such as Bruce Greenwood (Jack Dunphy) and Chris Cooper, Alvin Dewey) the film exhibits the enormous talent, and human flaws which made Capote a household word. Like an excellent novel, the movie is slow to build, but eventually achieves a touching tribute to the man.This is your comment, you may delete or edit it.

reviewText: The first of the two films made in 2005 about Truman Capote's writing of IN COLD BLOOD, CAPOTE got the lion's share of the critics' attention and won a Best Actor Oscar for Philip Seymour Hoffman as the eponymous writer who found the story that would make him rich in the murder of the Clutter family in Holcomb, Kansas in 1959. Of the two films (the other being INFAMOUS, with Toby Jones), CAPOTE is the more self-consciously artistic: it has gorgeous cinematography by Adam Kimmel of the haunted and empty Kansas plains (Manitoba being used as that state's stand-in), and a truly unforgettable scene where Capote sneaks into a Holcomb funeral parlor and opens the casket of Mrs. Clutter, only to find her face (blown away by a shotgun) swathed in muslin like something mysterious and sacerdotal.The film is quite fine on its own terms, and has a superlative performance by Catherine Keener as the author Harper Lee, who accompanied her childhood friend Capote to Holcomb for his first long research trip and who listens with patience and forbearance to her friend's egotistical and insensitive rants. The film has a lovely sense of eerie slow pacing to it, and its focus is squarely on Capote's mercurial and conflicted character, and how his career was both made and ruined by the story, especially after he became emotionally entangled with one of the Clutters' killers, Perry Smith (an intense Clifton Collins, Jr.). Hoffman's portrayal of Capote was widely (and deservedly) praised, although he does emphasize the writer's cruelty and spoiled selfishness over his simultaneously capabilities for great charm and kindness. The filmmakers made a conscious choice to omit Capote's high life among Manhattan's cafe society, which is emphasized much more in INFAMOUS; the most grievous mistake of both films is to give any sense of life or humanity to the poor dead Clutters themselves, so that in neither film do we have enough of a sense of the monstrousness of their murders: one of the greatest achievements of IN COLD BLOOD itself is to make the Clutters almost unbearably human in the day leading up to their deaths.

reviewText: "Capote" tells the story of the writing of the author's masterwork, "In Cold Blood," which itself narrated the aftermath of the brutal shotgun murders of a Kansas family of four by two drifters in November 1959. Inexplicably drawn to newspaper stories about the murders, writer Truman Capote begins what will become a 4-year odyssey to write about the murders and maybe become/stay famous as a result. Using his reputation as a famous author, as well as his considerable personal charm, Capote works his way past accepted social boundaries. He brazenly walks into the funeral parlor to personally view the corpses of the deceased. Invited into the local sheriff's apartment (via a link to the sheriff's wife, who is also a writer) he manages to make contact with one of the killers, imprisoned (weirdly) in a cell built into the kitchen. By fair means and foul, Capote lies, charms and ingratiates his way into obtaining the material he needs for his book -- all except for the crucial details of what happened on the night of the murders. His continued efforts to keep everyone feeding him sensitive and even damaging information -- while simultaneously reaping the benefits of public adulation -- is creepy in the extreme.Yet Capote is affected by his contact with the townsfolk and with the prisoners. He is tortured by the legal continuances that prevent him from getting closure. His desire to end the book becomes a means in itself, though it means the death of people he has come to care about."Capote" teaches a bit about the author's life, but much about his soul. If the film is true to life, Capote was transformed from a man-about-town into a caring human being who was all but destroyed by the experience of writing his book. Given Capote's insouciant reputation in later years, this was one part of the film did not ring true.Still, Philip Seymour Hoffman did a very fine job portraying the author's talent, intelligence, single-mindedness...and duplicity. If anything, his portrayal was rather restrained, given Capote's extravagant persona. Catherine Keener's portrayal of Capote's friend, author Harper Lee, was solid and grounded the movie in reality and a modicum of period social morality. Clifton Collins, Jr. gave a phenomenal performance as erudite, sensitive killer Perry Smith. The film was ensemble work of the highest caliber. I do wish the filmmakers had been bolder about placing Capote in relation to the morality of the late 1950s, which were notoriously less tolerant of rule-benders like Capote than we are today. Had the film been a bit less restrained, it might have been a shoo-in for the "Best Movie" Oscar.As it is, though, the movie tells a chilling and compelling tale of the writing of one of the 20th century's ground-breaking books. The movie's success can be measured in my visceral lack of interest in reading "In Cold Blood" in the foreseeable future!

reviewText: Picking stars is impossible -- this is a very good and well-made (5 stars), quite intriguing but unenjoyable (1 star) film.To start with -- the murder of the Clutters is so awful and senseless it defies reason.This DVD is dark dark dark, not only the murders but Capote's winter visits to Leavenworth prison in Kansas, such that the next film I watched, Sideways, looked upbeat and brimming with joy by comparison.We have Capote appropriately engrossed by these murders when he reads about them in the paper.Capote may have invented new journalism, or at least laid its foundations. He received unbelievable access to the sheriff and the murderers and manipulated all, such that today nearly 50 years later, it would be impossible for a journo to go around peaking in caskets or thumbing through the sheriff's interrogation notes.This is the first glamorization of losers that I can recall in modern history (maybe others can correct me if I am mistaken), a start of the trend that brings us to gangsta rap today.Finally, Philip Seymour Hoffman provides a near-perfect but just slightly over-the-top depiction of Truman Capote -- take a look at some interviews with the real-life Capote on [...] for interesting comparisons.PS -- One earlier reviewer stated that the murders  are never re-enacted. Oh yes they are! It's toward the end, and sketchy, but it's there.
summary: Makes 'Sideways' look like a laff riot

reviewText: Two very engaging and very compelling things are centerpieces for works that people keep coming back to again and again: psychopaths and artists. Especially when both are slightly insane or egotistic, the analysis of brains abnormal and uncomprehending are fascinating and wondrous motifs that re-occur in literature and media again and again.This movie has both, a very contradictory and egotistic mind, Truman Capote's, matched with the alarmingly sweet and charismatic mind of a psychopath, Perry Smith, who Truman falls in love with and interviews for research to write his best-selling and important work, In Cold Blood. The result is very affecting. Hoffman's zealous and defined portrayal of Capote is matched by the outstanding performance of Clifton Collin's Jr., the lonely and slightly terrifying face of a killer who is human and humanized.The real drama comes from Capote's terrifyingly manipulative mind. For someone who didn't know much about Capote, Hoffman's performance was simply shocking. The commercials and advertising and posters and the like would have you imagine that Capote was a very strong artistic trope, like other biopics that show brilliant artists and their troubles. However, a couple of things should be noted... first, this is not a biopic. Second, Capote's flamboyantly homosexual and confrontational controversial mannerisms both set the man himself apart from the type of character we like to see from artists, and also set Hoffman's performance apart from basically anything we've ever seen before.A side-result is a very discomforting and contradictory look. Capote lies, manipulates, cheats... and yet the presentation of these events help us concern ourselves with his character so much that we can't help but want every part of his innermost desires to actualize. We have a man who kills, but he's also lonely and afraid and willing to cling on to anybody who will give him attention. We empathize with characters we'd normally shun, yet simultaneously feel uncomfortable being so close to them, thus wanting to know more about them so that we can come to terms with who they are.And at the end, when we see the denouement of what is both a perverse and a relatable relationship, the movie centers in on Smith's heavy breathing as he awaits his doom and the audience breaths heavily along with him, feeling all hope begin to fade from the screen as the deranged Capote watches on. Now tell me that isn't great, great film-making.
summary: One wonders what goes through ones mine

reviewText: Neither the recent death of a good (in this film phenomenal) actor nor the Oscars (see "Shakespeare In Love" for how embarrassingly bad the academy's judgment can be) maketh a "tragically beautiful" movie.  Films have to be judged critically.In this case, Bennett Miller's "Capote" deserved every ounce of praise it garnered, mostly due to Hoffmann's unbelievable performance as Truman Streckfus Persons, a.k.a Truman Capote.  Capote's magnum opus "In Cold Blood" transformed the True Crime genre from a "a 10 cent novel" status to an actual genre, for better or worse, with its mercilessly objective and strangely artful tale of a brutal murder in a sleepy town in Holcomb, Kansas.  It also drew a lot of both wanted and unwanted (both were devoured by the author) attention to Capote as a public figure, many accusing him of beatifying Perry Smith and his partner in crime Richard Hicock.Philip Seymour Hoffmann's portrayal of Capote is indeed a once in a lifetime performance.  An undoubtedly difficult character to bring to the screen in all his vividness and petty ambition, Hoffmann rose to the challenge.  In every frame you see this charismatic opportunist and maybe 40 percent decent person use every angle he can to obtain what he really wants; intimate, uninterrupted conversations with Perry Smith (played by Clifton Collins, Jr. who has been one of my favorite deviants since his turn as "Caezar" in the underrated film "187" with Samuel L. Jackson) and access to everything about the case.The point of the movie is pretty clear and bares a fair resemblance to reality.  Capote was letting his emotions (for smith) drown him.  His actual intent was to extract what he could as an artist and make the cultural significance of the incident--two misfits committing mass mayhem in 1950's America without reason or cause--open up new ways of thinking to the reader.  Now, though, his innate selfishness and ambition were turning on him, as he had a feeling or two for the actual people involved and their lives.  As a result, he suffers greatly, and probably justly.I think this movie will stay in the lexicon of great film for some time.  Recommended for anyone who saw the original with Robert Blake or wants to see a tremendous actor give it his all.

reviewText: With "In Cold Blood", Truman Capote became America's most famous writer.  This movie shows that Capote sold his soul in order to produce the book.The book is about the cold blooded murders of a family in Kansas. Capote befriended Perry Smith, one of the killers.  He got Smith to confide in him at first by getting him an appellate lawyer who gave Smith some temporary relief through the appellate process.As Smith faced the death penalty and exhausted his appeals, the movie suggests that Capote deliberately refused to help Smith out beyond that first effort. It leaves the viewer wondering whether he may have had the chance to do so. If the movie accurately portrays Capote, it was Capote's realization that he cared more about his book than about his "friend" that tore his mind apart.As Capote himself said: "answered prayers cause more tears than those that remain unanswered".In the end, Capote got what he prayed for, but he also never wrote another book. The movie suggests he asked himself the question: "If I hadn't been so selfish, could I have saved Smith's life?
summary: Great depiction of a tormented mind

reviewText: Wow is all that I can say.  Philip Seymour Hoffman was just amazing and very deserving of his Oscar win for best actor in Capote.  His portrayal of Truman Capote during his writing of the non-fiction novel of "In Cold Blood" was just amazing.  This movie is not a typical Hollywood film, no CGI, no special effects, etc., some blood splattering, which was minimal, to illustrate the crime of which Capote's novel was based upon, no chases, no nothing, except a brilliant performance by Philip Seymour Hoffman and Catherine Keener.  What is amazing is the range to these two actors, they both can do comedy, both can do action and both can do a serious dialog driven film-What range and what perfect people to play these two famous people as Keener played the understudy, friend of Capote who had her own career with "To Kill a Mocking Bird."  I have seen all best pictures nominated except for Brokeback Mountain, therefore, I can not give an opinion of my choice for best picture.  However, when doing a prior review, I thought Munich was much better than Crash (which won), which would mean that it was better than all other best movie nominees that I have seen.  However, after seeing Capote, the screenplay, the adaptation, the actors, the subject matter, the editing as well as the filming of the movie would make me think that this is the movie to see-However, again, I haven't seen Brokeback Mountain, so I will reserve my choice until later.  The director, little known, first feature film will of course not get a nod because there were higher profile directors with Ang Lee (Brokeback Mountain) and Steven Spielberg (Munich), etc.,.  However, for those who want to see a wonderful, eccentric performance, one that mimics the life and times of one of America's best authors, you have to see this.  Philip Seymour Hoffman had it down-He nailed it.  He nailed Capote feminism, quirkiness, manipulation, glib, self absorbing, his need to be the center of attention among his metamorphous to being a caring, loving person of life, not necessarily of the two murderers that his novel is based upon, but his love of life for all.  Capote (or Philip Seymour Hoffman) was a master storyteller with his mentioning of one of the deaths that the pillow was placed under the victim perfectly and the victim was shot with a shotgun, like being put to sleep.  There is a lot of information available on Capote, but to narrow it down to the period after "Breakfast at Tiffany's" to the period of the film, I believe three or four years of his life during his research for "In Cold Blood" was amazingly done.  The movie left you leaving did Capote use these people (the murderers) to make his novel or did he treasure life so much that he thought that these murderers should not die?  I don't know what his motive was, but I do know, as Capote and his publisher indicated that this novel was the start of a new way that authors write books.  Capote said that "When I think how good this novel can be, I can't breath." makes me feel his motive was his book.  This movie is a keeper.

reviewText: I've never read In Cold Blood--only a few short stories and excerpts from Answered Prayers. By the time I was old enough to be aware of who Truman Capote was, he was an object of scorn and ridicule by the popular press and had alienated most of his socialite friends because of Answered Prayers.So for a long time, it was a mystery to me how this broken, alcoholic could once have been so celebrated.There are many layers and nuances in this film but the classic tragedy is what has stayed with me the longest. Truman Capote makes the essential Faustian bargain: he receives the fame and praise he so desperately seeks by lying and manipulating but once he gets what he wants: a book that sets new conventions for True Crime stories, he can't live with himself.This is so beautifully played out in the movie's climax when Capote visits the two men immediately prior to their executions. He tries to say something and can only manage choked sobs. It is Perry, the man about to be hung, that consoles Capote.Another point raised during the film is that Truman Capote was not without people who genuinely loved and cared about him. In particular, his lover, Jack Dunphy and his childhood friend, Harper Lee. But it isn't enough and by running after what he wanted but didn't need, Capote essentially anniliates himself.In our celebrity-obsessed culture, this film quietly and truthfully paints a picture of the price many pay for seeking the illusion.

reviewText: Philip Seymour Hoffman's uncanny portrayal of brilliant misfit Truman Capote is reason enough to see this vivid, unnerving film, but the focus on his writing of "In Cold Blood" lets us peer into the tortured psyche of a man who always felt alone and set apart, with only his words to win him acknowledgment. Though Truman bonds with Smith as a fellow outcast (with homo-erotic undertones also evident), he also misleads and manipulates the convict to achieve his own literary ends. Collins scores as a downright spooky Smith, and Oscar-nominated Catherine Keener does a nicely measured turn as Capote's childhood friend, novice author Harper Lee. A layered, complex piece about a tragic event, and one profoundly disillusioned man who used it to create his last, most enduring work.

reviewText: vant & celebrity writer in New York City. Not a biography, but the story of his sometimes tortuous journey writing his masterpiece, "In Cold Blood." It started as an article for the New Yorker then he decided to make it a book. It concerns the murder of an entire farm family in Kansas. The killers are arrested, & in fairly short order are sentenced to death. Phillip Seymour won the academy award & is dead on. He looks like Capote & even has his mannerisms & speech patterns down. The book took over Capote's life with brief interuptions for several years. He met many rural folks from the area & develops close relationships in the course of his research, including with the condemned men. His repugnance to the death penalty puts him at odds with the local people & his own best interest. He helps the men postpone their execution. He could not finish his book until they die. At some point, he ceases to help them, perhaps feeling he is being used or realizing the condemned start to believe they will not be hanged. They are of course & Capote never finishes another book. An excellent film & deserving of it's awards.
summary: It gives you just a taste  of  Truman Capote's life as a bon vi-

reviewText: This was a wonderful film.  The "buzz" it generated was well-deserved due to its writing, acting and cinematography.Especially underestimated is the impact of the last item.  Since the writing is so good, and since it's about writing, the production values are easy to underestimate or overlook.  Great care went into set decoration, period costume and such.  However, the usage of color was agreed before the first shot was taken.  Unbelievably, they decided not to use any blues or reds, and the result is an unrelentingly bleak look.  It was shot in and around Winnepeg, as a proxy for late-50s Kansas.  The result was just as intended.  Wheat and flat and snow and a terrible sweep of the soul.Truman's essential vulnerability is sacrificed in pursuit of "a whole new kind of writing."  The end result, arguably, is the sort of heartless exploitative journalism that predominates writing today.Others here say that it also destroyed Capote.  I disagree.  They way this movie depicts him, Capote was already destroyed.  It starts when he pays a railway porter to tell him how great his writing is, right at the beginning of the film.  Anyone who is such a slave to recognition and praise is already finished, given the emptiness of the sought-after reward.To understand how we moved from the "innocent" 1950s to where we are to day, watch this movie.

reviewText: Have you ever read or heard of an instance of a woman falling in love with a jailed murderer and thought, "How pathetic is that!"?On November 14, 1959 in Kansas, four members of the Clutter family were brutally murdered by Perry Smith and Richard Hickock. After years on Death Row and multiple appeals, they were hung by the neck until dead on April 14, 1965. Truman Capote's book based on the crime, IN COLD BLOOD, was published in 1966.CAPOTE is the cinematic depiction of Truman's 4-year obsession with the case, and his growing emotional attachment to Smith, as he researched material for IN COLD BLOOD. The author is played by Philip Seymour Hoffman, Smith by Clifton Collins, and Hickock by Mark Pellegrino.Hoffman's Capote is 5 stars and worthy of an Oscar nomination. I would be satisfied if he wins, regardless of the others nominated for Best Actor in pictures that may not even have been released yet, because his performance as the brilliant, tormented, self-affected, and pathetic writer is that excellent. That being said, however, the film is a joyless and tedious character study that is one of the most boring films I've seen recently; my wife had to jab my side to keep me eyelids-up. The only highpoints for me were the achingly beautiful, but all too infrequent, wide-angle shots of the "Kansas" landscape (actually filmed in Manitoba), and the visual jolt when, towards the film's end, Smith reveals to Capote what actually happened in the Clutter farmhouse.CAPOTE is a must-see movie for any admirer of Truman and his writings, but it just wasn't for me.
summary: One man's obsession is another man's soporific

reviewText: The first time I saw "Capote" (the day it was released on DVD), I appreciated it for Philip Seymour Hoffman's performance and it's atmosphere. That's about it. I gave it a good grade and moved on, looking at the movie as a disappointment when it caught my eye at a video store. I usually agree with a lot of famous film critic's selections on their yearly Top 10 lists. I don't always agree with the order of the list, but I usually agree that they're great films. So when I didn't like Capote, I was surprised. I hadn't really considered watching it again, until I saw the movie at my local library. It was free and I had nothing else to watch and watching it now I appreciate it a lot more...And enjoyed it a lot more. This movie does not achieve greatness merely from a great performance or a great atmosphere. Those two things help it to achieve its brilliance, but there's a lot more I missed in my first viewing. First of all, I want to talk about Hoffman's Oscar winning performance. Yes he won the Oscar, beating out three other actors who played real life people, but people still say that he didn't deserve it. People have said his performance was mimicry, while someone like Joaquin Phoenix managed to really show the shaded areas of the person they were playing. This is an unfair statement. If you weren't doing some form of mimicry while playing Truman Capote, you'd have no film. In playing someone like Johnny Cash, you don't need to sound like him. In playing Truman Capote, mastering his speech and his mannerisms is essential. The movie has an Oscar nominated script by actor Dan Futterman, who has (like most other screen-biographers) opted out of a childhood-to-death biopic...Instead Futterman chronicles what could be classified as the most important time in Truman Capote's life. It's 1959 and in a small Kansas town called Halcomb, a family of four is brutally murdered. This sends the town into frenzy and gives novelist/screenwriter Truman Capote an idea for a newspaper article. He travels to Kansas with his friend, "To Kill a Mockingbird" novelist Nelle "Harper" Lee (Catherine Keener, in an Oscar worthy, and nominated, performance), and begins research. Soon, the killers are caught and Capote finds himself surprised. Men, whom he thought at first would be hardened violent criminals are two dim-witted men named Perry Smith and Dick Hickock (Clifton Collins Jr. & Mark Pellegrino). Capote soon finds that he's not writing a newspaper article at all, but a novel...A non-fiction novel, the first of its kind. He begins interviewing Smith and Hickok, but finds a connection with Smith...A man Capote basically befriends, all the while using him for his own exploits. The movie does a great job of showing the different shades of Truman Capote. The outspoken, talkative cartoonish-voiced man who would bring life to various parties. A sweet man, whom people loved to talk too. A dedicated, smart novelist with a fantastic memory. A man hell-bent on writing a great novel, despite the fact a friend has to die for him to complete it. The scenes between Capote and Smith are truly heartbreaking. In fact, it almost seems (at times) that Capote is more of a bad guy than Smith is. Chris Cooper also turns in a strong performance as the head of the murder investigation, Alvin Dewey. "Capote" was nominated for several Academy Awards, including Best Picture...The only Oscar went to Best Actor for Hoffman, but the film could've easily taken Cinematography and Art Direction trophies. The movie has a stark, gray atmosphere to it. This helps remind the audience of how depressing the movie truly is. I don't believe there's one shot (except for a scene in Spain) where there's sunlight. One of the strongest performances in the film belongs to Collins Jr. as Smith. Collins is an actor I haven't seen in any movies previously, but he plays Smith very convincingly. In the scene where Smith finally opens up to Capote about the murders, the look he gets in his eyes and the way the cadence of his voice changes shows that this guy could become a legend in the years to come. While I admit that this isn't the most entertaining film in the world (I found myself looking at the clock a few times), it was one of the best films of 2005 and it is very engrossing. One other thing I want to add. There's some great scenes (that many could claim are out of place) where Capote will talk about various exploits. One, which I found amusing, was about the writing process of a John Huston film called "Beat the Devil." While he doesn't actually say the title, so most people won't notice...He talks about the director and the star of the film, Humphrey Bogart. If you know what movie he is talking about and know about Bogart, this story is particularly amusing. One of the things that works best about a scene like that is you realize that if you were at a party with Capote and he was talking about something that you knew about, he would really hold your attention. Great acting, a solid script, great directing, awesome cinematography, a wonderful atmosphere, although does grow a bit dull at times...This is a movie you won't want to miss.GRADE: A-

reviewText: I almost never watch modern films...they bore me. They insult me. The staff of millions required to create them, assumes I am a dingdong (I guess...), as nothing is left undone or unsaid. This film is entirely different...i was fastened to my chair like a tick on the plump butt of a big heifer...I read everything Capote wrote & I do this yearly, because it is so damned great. I find the classics (Other Voices, Grass Harp etc..) as being the finest literature ever birthed on American soil...(but, let me add Ross Lockridge's Raintree County to that statement...). Whatever, the case...one wonders about Capote, his southern bent....his descent into what became his isolationist demise into what were his only solace in the end (drugs & booze)...perhaps it was In Cold Blood that broke him. I hesitated to watch this film because Capote is, despite his flaws, a sacred object to me...yet, I could not resist the movie in the end! The acting was so steeped in what certainly must be Truman Capote,spectacularly! I also loved the actress who portrayed the calm and anchored, Harper Lee. Really, all fans of classic American literature should watch this attempt to capture the essence of Truman Capote without the effect of resultant caricature. It was done here.
summary: A stunning performance...no doubt about it!

reviewText: Philip Seymour Hoffman seems to climb inside the skin of Truman Capote in his depiction of the author of "In Cold Blood".  A troubled, alcoholic, gay man in an era when homosexuality was not widely condoned, Capote becomes engrossed in the story of the brutal slaying of a Kansas family of four.  He travels to Kansas with his friend Harper Lee (author of "To Kill A Mockingbird") and witnesses the arrest, trial, and imprisonment of the two men responsible for the murders.  At first Capote plans to write a short story about the killings, but as he digs further into the circumstances, he realizes that it has the makings of a great novel.  The film focuses on his conversations with one of the killers, Perry Smith, who has a background which is remarkably similar to Capote's.  A friendship develops, which surprises both men.  Ultimately, however, Capote becomes anxious to finish the book and this can only happen after the men are executed.  Capote treads a fine line of friendship vs. his own convenience and the viewer sees his moral fiber quickly erode.  This is a well-made film which poses some very interesting ethical questions.

reviewText: MOVIE: The film's opening scene is Truman Capote at a party, and he is standing with a drink in his hand while telling a story. Everyone standing around him is laughing and he is there almost performing a show for them. Here is where we have a first glimpse of the eccentric character of Truman Capote. Capote (pronounced 'cah-poh-tee') is brilliant film that takes an inside look at two different men. Here we have Truman Capote (Phillip Seymore Hoffman) who is a man who is absolutly full of himself. He loves to hear himself talk, and he loves it when people compliment his writing. Why shouldn't he love it, his work is incredibly brilliant. He is searchinh for the topic of his next article, and he picks a murder that happened in rural Kansas. Four people were murdered when two men broke and entered their homes. Truman travels by train to the small town along with Harper Lee (Catherine Keener) to interview people who were assosiated with the murder. The two brothers accused of the murders are put to death, and Truman befriends one of them. He visits him in his cell and talks with him about who he is as a person. Capote decides that he wants to write a book instead of an article when he sees how interesting his subject is. They share stories about their pasts and how both of them seem to be outcasts of society. However, this is where the murderer, Perry Smith, actually finds a friend in Truman. Truman on the other hand is only after information that will make is book a masterpiece. As time goes by Truman starts to find decency within this man, and actually tries to fight for him so that his death sentence is appealed. After three years Truman's book is almost finished, but he still has no idea why the murders happened. When he finally probes the information out of Perry a whole new side of this man is revealed. The film is psychologically haunting. We have Truman Capote, a very eccentric yet brilliant homosexual writer. We also have Perry Smith, the murderer who seems to be a decent person and claims that they never meant to kill that family. The film digs deep on Truman's character, and just enough for Perry's. When the end comes and we learn the truth about the murders, we see a change in both characters. The film also boasts some very subtle yet amazing cinematography. Almost every shot is framed through a window or a doorway. In the jail we have some shots framed through the bars. The film also has some amazing lighting, and the lighting on the faces is another subtlety to notice. The haunting score by Mychael Danna is amazing. The score is nothing more than simple notes on the piano, very similar to Newman's score for Road To Perdition. The film is a deep and dark look into the human mind, and human emotion. I have read some reviews that suggest that there may have been a sexual attraction between Capote and Smith, but I did not see that at all. I felt it was just an interest in a person who is deemed a monster yet is a very poignant person. The film was brilliant and haunting, and is worth your while.ACTING: Phillip Seymore Hoffman gives a tour de force performance of Truman Capote. Not only did he capture the pompous nature of the writer, but he captured the emotion within him as a human being. Clifton Collins Jr. gives an amazing performance as the very ambiguous Perry Smith. The two actors also play off each other very well, their acting envelopes the audience into the atmosphere of the film and makes their conversations all the more emotional. Both actors are worthy of nominations, and Hoffman may have given a performance that translates into Oscar.BOTTOM LINE: While some people may find the first quarter of the film slow, it picks up and ends up being one of those movies that stays with you long after you see it. The performances are stellar, and they add to the film's effect on the audience. Bennet Miller's direction is on the mark as he spends the right amount of time with each character, and he sets up the third act of the film perfectly
summary: A Brilliant Film, Rich With Character & Emotion. A Tour De Force Performance From Hoffman

reviewText: While "Capote" structurally is a textbook-ready slice off the old American filmmaking pie -- healthy doses of foreshadowing in chiseled dialogue and little need to read between the lines -- the film's message neatly exposes the rotting underbelly of the American dream. The film, if it tends to take the life of Truman Capote and boil it down to the meaty part of the microscope slide (if you will), is little more than the mundane allegory of the poisoning of power, the Midas touch, but under Phillip Seymour Hoffman's guidance, the writer is given an almost spiritual charm. It's through Hoffman's subtle portrayal of human fragility that you find yourself empathizing with Capote, who, as it turns out, is the true antagonist of the film -- not the misguided killers due for the chopping block.

reviewText: Capote is one of the more thought provoking movies I've seen this year, in which viewers are given a long, almost agonizing look into the heart, soul and angst of author/celebrity Truman Capote.Philip Seymour-Hoffman is fabulous in his portrayal of Truman Capote who sets out to investigate the murder of a family in small town Kansas. Capote's original magazine article grows into a book as the writer is drawn into the horror of the murder and the shaping events in the brutal killers' pasts.As Capote unravels the truth of the heinous crime the viewer is given glimpses into his own tragedies and the results of those in his life, and his obsessive connection to one of the two men who await execution.This is not light entertainment. And the subject matter guarantees some gruesome elements which are there. If you love to look into a soul and discover what makes it unique and fragile, you may find that this film is a gem.Because of my visit to Capote's mind, I intend to watch Infamous and read In Cold Blood.

reviewText: This is a good movie.  It's an incredible first effort for director Bennett Miller.  And it's a stellar (not a Hollywood-star stellar, but brilliant stellar) introduction to one of the most intriguing 20th century English-speaking literary figures this side of Oscar Wilde. An introduction that leaves a body wanting to know more about this ascerbic wit, who once threw the world's most talked-about party (the Black and White affair in 1968), but could not bring himself to write a productive word after the  events chronicled in this film, between 1959 and 1965.  All I knew about Capote before seeing this film was that he wrote "In Cold Blood" (which I read only in anticipation of watching this film), that he had a high-pitched, nasally voice, that he showed up on late-night TV shows a lot when I was a kid, and I've wondered since if he was gay.  But I had no desire or inclination to learn anything else about him, or suspect that he had any real influence on American literature as a whole.Now that I've seen the film (and know that my gay-dar is relatively effective)I do have a hunger to read more of his works, especially those done initially for the New Yorker, such as his coverage of an African American opera company tour of the Soviet Union in 1956 (during which he apparently gave the hosts, not the artists, scathing reviews, much to Moscow's dismay).The cinematography, acting, and sparse score of "Capote"indicate immediately that this film will be different:  gray cumulus clouds hang pregnant over a Kansas field where a lone '56 Buick sits at a silent farmhouse.  There is a breeze, but there is no music to tell you what to expect.  A little girl is on the doorstop knocking (not ringing a bell), then walking in the house to discover the evidence that will start "In Cold Blood". Jump cut immediately to the New York skyline where we do hear music, but it's music from a party, not a movie score, where Truman Is Holding Court, sitting  while others stand enraptured by one of his anecdotes, at which, of course, they all laugh.  Seymour and everyone here is very natural, very fresh, very comfortable with each other (or, like in the case with the sherriff of Holcomb, very comfortable being uncomfortable with Seymour's character).And there is certainly some tension in Capote's relationship with both perpetrators, Dick and Perry.  Even though he feels he can win Perry over, Perry senses this, and there is a genuine back and forth with the characters in the film.In summary, the acting is great, the cinematography is great, the development of most of the main characters, namely Truman, his friend Nelle (Harper Lee), and Perry Smith, is fairly good.There is something missing in the story, however.  Within the tension of the problem that Capote has set for himself (to want Perry to love him enough to share everything with him, but to want Perry to die so that the book can be over with), he and his friends can recognize his dilemma.  And his friends chide him for it.Nowhere, however, does anyone scold him for his betrayal of the Clutters or those who loved them.What is evident is Capote's disgust when Perry tells him coolly, "Mr Cutter was a nice gentleman...I thought so right up to the moment that I cut his throat." But this sign that maybe he is remembering the victims of the crime seems undone by his lover's and friend's insistence that he's being selfish to avoid helping or seeing the accused killlers further.I would have liked a more evident struggle with this issue.  For instance, surely some of the people Capote interviewed and sympathized with about the murders must have known he had gone to Lansing and Leavenworth to visit with the prisoners.  Did they contact him about that?  What did they say?In the meantime, I will look forward to both Mr. Miller and Mr. Seymour's next efforts.  And "The Capote Reader" (which includes that story of the 1956 USSR tour) now adorns my wishlist, in case anyone is in a giving mood.
summary: "I thought [he was nice] right up to the moment that I cut his throat.

reviewText: As a reporter for the *New Yorker*, Truman Capote boards a train to Holcomb, Kansas to report on a horrible crime where an entire family was murdered.  He is joined by his assistant and best friend, Nelle Harper Lee, who later wrote *To Kill a Mockingbird*.Perry Smith and Richard Hickock were soon captured in Las Vegas and brought back to Holcome to answer for the murders.  Capote befriends them both to write his article.  However, Capote develops some chemistry with Smith and decides to write a book instead.This goal to write a book causes a strain on Capote's relationship with his lover, who was also a writer.  Anyways, the relationship between Capote and Smith is interesting.  Capote needs Smith to retell the night of the murder.  Instead, Smith talks about everything else.  In retaliation, Capote withholds information whenver Smith inquires about the book.It takes Capote four years to write this book.  Initially, Capote is excited about this prospect.  However, as time goes by, he becomes depressed, especially when Smith and Hickock lose their appeal, with the Supreme Court, from execution.  He's so depressed that can't even put aside his feelings and offer congratulations to Lee on her new novel.When all is done, Capote manages to complete his book, *In Cold Blood*.  He never wrote another book afterwards.Philip Seymour Hoffman did a good job as Capote.  I liked him the moment I first saw him in *Talented Mr. Ripley*.  He has never disappointed me since.  This was indeed his best film yet.

reviewText: To say I was underwhelmed by "Capote" is like saying two buildings were destroyed in New York on 9/11. After reading about this film for months and seeing Philip Seymour walk away with the statuette at the Oscars, I had high hopes for a drama built around real events. Turns out the dramatic part occurred, but without satisfaction for the high hopes.Among other things, this film is essentially a 110-minute whisper over one of the most startling real life events in the last half of the 20th century. Not only did the Nebraska murders teach the Midwest to lock their doors at night, it ushered in a new form of literature with the nonfiction novel. This had previously been introduced via Norman Mailer's work centering on World War II and Capote finished it off in the same way Alexander Graham Bell perfected the telephone that was invented by someone else.The history portrayed in the film was useful insofar as I had no idea Capote was also author of both "Breakfast At Tiffany's" in novel and film treatment forms. I was also surprised to learn, through my own research while watching the movie, that Capote did not author another tome of much popular value outside it and "In Cold Blood".While Hoffman probably earned his award for this film, I recall the real Truman Capote and Hoffman ain't it. He is more a caricature of the real man, who was perhaps the ugliest man that ever lived in the United States. Hoffman not only presented a Richard Gere caricature of Capote, with his beautiful facial lines set against the real life Capote's egg-shaped head, his elegance and eloquence were more a match for a character at Tiffany's than for the real flesh and blood man.No matter, I suppose, for now this is a done deal and most people accepted it as the best characterization to date. Still, that characterization is rarely enough to carry the heavy weight of this film, which is bolstered by fine support from the likes of Chris Cooper. The wieight I refer to is the feature moving at a glacial pace in darkened scenes that mimic film noir.While perhaps captivating on the big screen in the mall, the molasses in February pace caused me jitters and unease watching at home. In addtion, the overriding darkness is metaphor to the ugliness of the story, no doubt, but still works against the film as entertainment. While leaving no doubt this is important stuff, it nonetheless comes off as more an exercise in doggedness than anything equivalent to fun.In prior films of the nature, including Cliff Robertson's Oscar-winning characterization as "Charly" and Al Pacino's prize as the blind tough guy in "Scent of A Woman" -- terrific portrayals inside similarly mediocre films -- the producers added life to the bland stories and critics didn't offer undeserved awards to the slow-moving beast of a movie. They'd have done well to adhere to that here, too.

reviewText: Knowing his downward trajectory during the last 15 years of his life makes "Capote," the outstanding film about Truman Capote's years researching and writing "In Cold Blood," even more riveting. The film constructs, with not one extraneous scene or unnecessary bit of dialog, an understanding of his place in literary society, and his chameleon-like ease at blending into the lives of the people whom he wanted to capture and luring them into trusting him with their lives and stories. His ability to say exactly what a publisher, a murderer, his lover, his oldest friend wanted to hear in order to court their love or trust, and seem to mean each word he said, is juxtaposed perfectly with his ability to cut them off at the knees, dismiss them, insult them, or ignore them when their needs don't suit his.The Oscar-winning performance by Philip Seymour Hoffman is astonishing, not only because his impersonation of Capote's strained, high, tiny voice and his fussy mannerisms is so remarkably good, but because he moves effortlessly between charm and seemingly endless empathy to self-absorption of enormous proportion so smoothly and naturally. We both admire and revile him. In their roles, excellent actors Chris Cooper and Catherine Keener show indulgence and affection for him, as well as wariness and disgust with his deceit of others, of them, of himself. The script is often spare and the pacing, while perfect, is never rushed; what is not said by the characters is as important and full of meaning as the well-crafted dialog. We learn just enough about any character, any situation, to be able to piece together what its meaning will be to those involved. His actions and the reactions of others are carefully calibrated so that we are never in the dark as to what is going on or how his actions will reverberate, but we are trusted to be able to let the story build in our minds; the writer, director, and actors don't spoonfeed us but deftly piece the feelings, words, and actions of the characters together so that the story builds and intermeshes exactly as it should. This is how a subtle story should be told.

reviewText: Ostensibly "Capote" is the story of Truman Capote writing "In Cold Blood: A True Account of a Multiple Murder and Its Consequences," about the 1959 murders of the Clutter family in Holcomb, Kansas.  The book is considered a landmark in American letters for epitomizing, if not creating (as Capote claimed), the new genre of the non-fiction novel, wherein the traditional conventions of literature were applied to a crime story.  However, by the time we fade to black and get to the title cards that let us know the rest of story, it becomes clear that "Capote" is trying to provide insights as to why the author of "Breakfast at Tiffany's" never finished another novel.  Publishing the novel changed American literature, but writing it changed Capote.When the Clutters are murdered, Capote reads of the story in "The New York Times" and decides he wants to write about it for "The New Yorker."  The editor, William Shawn (Bob Balaban), agrees and Capote heads for Kansas.  He connects with the head of the investigation, Alvin Dewey (Chris Cooper), through his wife, Marie Dewey (Amy Ryan), who is dazzled by a celebrity from New York City.  Capote does not care if the killers are caught or not, but Alvin Dewey does.  Once Perry Smith (Clifton Collins, Jr.) and Richard Hickock (Mark Pellegrino) are captured, convicted, and sentenced to death, Capote's biggest concern is keeping the two murderers alive long enough to hear what happened that night.  He helps get them new lawyers for a series of appeals, trying to get Smith, the one of the pair with whom he has established a real rapport, to provide the details.  In time that will happen, but then a horrified Capote realizes he cannot complete the book because Smith and Hickock are still alive and the story will not be over until they are executed.Capote is accompanied to Kansas by his friend, Nelle Harper Lee (Catherine Keener), who in 1959 has recently finished her book about children and a dead bird, and is trying to find a publisher.  I am drawn to the irony that Capote and Lee worte what are arguably the two most important books produced in my life time, yet neither wrote another (and there are those who claim Capote co-authored her book).  I know enough about "To Kill a Mockingbird," which was developed from a series of short stories based on incidents in her family history, to accept the idea that Lee had but one novel in her and that when that book is selected novel of the century there is nothing to complain about.  But it is impossible to believe the same of Capote, and the film that bears his name gives us some indication of what is lost when the author gives a public reading from his book and it becomes clear to us that "In Cold Blood" is as good as Capote claims.In a year when three of the Oscar nominations for Best Actor are based on not only real people but famous people whose way of talking (and singing) are well known, Hoffman's performance stands out for the moments when we are not listening to Capote's affected speech.  It does not take long in the film to distinguish between the Capote of the cocktail parties, when he clearly knows he is on stage and the one that can be persuasive when out and about in the real world.  But for me the key moments are when Capote is silent, observing and reacting to people and things.  If Hoffman wins the Best Actor Oscar tomorrow night as is expected, part of it will be because of the respected body of work he has produced in films over the last decade, but the majority will be because of this finely nuanced performance that is so far removed from the caricature it could have been that we accept him as Capote and are suitable impressed.
summary: Truman Capote goes to Kansas to write "In Cold Blood"

reviewText: Fortunately, I bought it cheap - and it remains on my "mediocre" DVD shelf. I guess I should have taken more hints from the title. It's mostly about CAPOTE, not the murderers. Hoffman deserved that oscar, but I was just a little bored with the story.After reading "In Cold Blood," I was really intrigued with the Clutter family, the setting, the method of the murders, and the murderers themselves. We got to see a little of Perry in the movie, but not much of Dick.  And it seemed as if the filmmakers wanted us to sympathize with the murderers and not look as closely to their victims.I must admit I sympathized with Perry a little, not for getting caught and imprisoned, but because Capote was using him and lying to him for his book. The lie about not knowing what the title was called especially irritated me. If he's going to make an effort to write about a crime truthfully, he could at least be honest with the subjects of his writing.I did appreciate the violent flashbacks, but I wished those scenes had been extended. Crime scenes fascinate me, as I'm sure they do others, and I bet I wasn't the only disappointed viewer.It's nice to know that Capote was as self-centered, whiny, and elitist as I thought he was. I wanted to smack him when he barely gave any attention to his best friend's (Harper Lee) book and movie. Like he didn't consider "To Kill a Mockingbird" good literature, "real" art, intellectual, or whatever.And yes, I think the criminals deserved the death penalty. Oh wait, hanging is so cruel and unusual, some might say. Well, what about the brutal slayings? Propping up the son's head with a pillow "for his comfort" didn't make the crimes any less cruel. If you're truly concerned with someone's comfort, then don't harm them at all.In general - interesting, but not nearly as creepy and haunting as the book.
summary: Why oh why did I buy this?

reviewText: If Philip Seymour Hoffman does not get the Academy Award for Best Actor, then the thinking of the Academy is seriously off base. Having seen Mr. Hoffman in a number of other films, to watch him do Truman Capote here was more than a revelation--it was breathtaking.It was absolutely Mr. Hoffman channeling Truman Capote. No other description does his performance justice. THIS is the mark of acting that transcends being even great--it is astounding. If you saw him as the doofy slob boyfriend of Hope Davis in "Next Stop Wonderland", nothing will prepare you for his performance here. Even if you saw him as the gay neighbor of Robert DeNiro in "Flawless"--even that is a trace of the brilliance that bursts on the screen here in "Capote".He forges a relationship with convicted mass murderer Perry Smith that is heartbreaking and more emotionally powerful than any conventional love story has portrayed a relationship in many years on screen. Then he can turn right around and exchange bon mots at a cocktail party and be completely convincing as a quick-witted social butterfly with a sly biting sense of humor.I have to confess that I was riveted to the screen. Catherine Keener was also really good, as was Chris Cooper and Bob Balaban and Bruce Greenwood and the actor playing Perry Smith (in fact, the latter was excellent). But this is really Hoffman's film. I think you can tell that he knows he had great material to work with; the screenwriter, Dan Futterman, did a tremendous job of conveying Capote's personality in cinematic form and Hoffman takes maximum advantage of that terrific script by nailing the character from the get-go.Right from the start we can see this is no ordinary character--it's not just that Capote is gay; he's also extremely intelligent and spoiled and at the same time extremely emotionally sensitive. This is a combination of personality traits that is almost unique--or at the very least, very very rare."Capote" deals with the author's life during the time of the writing of his masterwork, "In Cold Blood"--from the moment he sees the original article in the NY Times describing the grisly murders in Kansas to the execution of the two murderers, spanning more than five years. During that time, Capote spent a lot of time interviewing Perry Smith, one of the two killers, and as much or more time in the company of his research assistant, Nell Harper Lee, who, during the course of her work with Capote, attained fame and glory herself with the publication of "To Kill a Mockingbird" which then became a film. Catherine Keener as Lee is great.This is a must-see film and, along with "The Squid and the Whale" should be counted as one of the top ten American films of 2005.

reviewText: I've always thought that Philip Seymour Hoffman was a wonderful actor.  And this film, which will probably win him an Oscar nomination, really brings out his talent.  He's cast as Truman Capote, the eccentric writer who became famous for his book "In Cold Blood".  At that time, Capote was already well known for "Breakfast at Tiffany's", and was a writer for the New Yorker.  Highly intelligent and an eccentric, he was public about his lifestyle and was known for his exaggerated effete mannerisms and self absorption.The film is the story of his obsessive research for "In Cold Blood" and his relationship with the murderers of a Kansas farm family in 1959.  Chris Cooper is cast as the policeman in town who allows Capote access to the arrested men.  Catherine Keener is cast Nelle Harper Lee, who wrote "To Kill A Mockingbird".  She a dear friend of Capote's since childhood and traveled with him to help him with his research.  She and Capote smoke a lot of cigarettes and drink a lot of martinis.Capote was instrumental in helping the killers get postponements and reprieves after they were convicted.  This went on for five long years during which time Capote became more and more devoted to one of them, Perry Smith, played by Clifton Collins, Jr.  Their relationship was complex because if Perry admitted too many details, he would be re-enforcing the fact that he committed the crime. I applaud the director, Bennett Miller, for being able to capture these multifaceted elements of each of the characters.This is a really fine film.  I see many awards in its future.But then, why was I bored?  The whole film was only 90 minutes long and I must have dosed off a half dozen times.  Perhaps it was just too subtle for my taste.  After I got to understand Capote's character, the rest of the film dragged.  There was also no surprise about the outcome because I was aware of the actual story.  So therefore, ever though I do recommend Capote, I cannot give it the rave reviews that I think it deserves.  I suggest you do see Capote though.  And make up your own mind.
summary: Philip Seyour Hoffman should get an Academy Award for this role.

reviewText: Having read and loved Truman Capote's masterpiece In Cold Blood, I was eager to see the "story" behind the creation of this book.  In Capote, what I got was a performance and script so understated it was boring, dull, and slow.  There is no action or even a climax to the film.  Non-literary, non-intellectual, non-egghead types would be bored to death with the lack of tension and conflict in the film.  The film is about four brutal killings, but the murders are never re-enacted.  You see a shotgun blast from a window, hear a girl scream as she finds the bodies, see a killer going up the stairs with a rifle, and see a body lying on its side on the bed with blood on the wall, but this is not enough to bring the terrible events to life.However, if you are familiar with Capote and are in awe of In Cold Blood, you will probably enjoy the film.
summary: Film Won't Mean Much for Those Unfamiliar With In Cold Blood

reviewText: Naturally, the story of an ambitious eccentric who inserts himself into a major news event with seemingly little concern for the real people involved has great resonance with me. I probably haven't identified so strongly with a character on screen since PSH's earlier role in Happiness. Hoffman doesn't just play Truman Capote, he IS Truman Capote, in a performance so convincing that even months after the film's release, Liza Minelli is still calling him up at 3:00 am and demanding to raid his Quaalude stash. The film also provides fascinating insight into the literary world of the 1960s; who knew that famed To Kill A Mockingbird author Harper Lee (played by the exquisite Catherine Keener) was also one of the world's first "fag hags"?It's in the story of Capote's relationship with a convicted killer, Robert Blake, that we see what an innovator the man really was. We witness how he pioneered the "non-fiction novel", a concept which the likes of James Frey have recently picked up and taken to new heights. With that in mind, it's too bad that Truman largely operated before the age of crack and Oprah because he really could've been somebody. Instead he became a sad, wasted figure chatting it up with celebrities at drug-and-sex-infested parties at Studio 54 - ie. living the American dream. (...)The whole film made me want to pull out my well-worn, yellowed-out copy of In Cold Blood and actually read it instead of wearing it and coloring it yellow.So cheers to Capote - the Best Picture of the year!

reviewText: Philip Seymour Hoffman gives an Oscar winning performance as Truman Capote, a wonderful writer from Alabama with the whiniest voice I have ever heard.  Enjoying the intellectual writing, nightlife in New York City, Truman hears about a murder of an entire family in Kansas.  He decides right away what his new writing topic will be and with support from his employer, The New Yorker, he goes down with his friend played by Catherine Keener, to get the story.  The film takes place over 5 years as Capote interacts first with the town people, the law enforcement people and finally the murderers themselves.  The most intense and troubling relationships are with the prisoners while they await trail and later execution.  Capote hires lawyers to help them but after they confess and then tell him how the murders take place he distances himself from them until the very end.  A good parallel movie to In Cold Blood and a good introduction to the book and the author.
summary: Excellent Film of Truman Capote During In Cold Blood Period

reviewText: When he held aloft the Oscar for "Best Actor" -- at this year's Academy Awards show -- Phil Hoffman didn't have any time (in a 60-second acceptance speech) to recall the  pleasures of filming "Capote" here, in "the world's coldest major city" (according to the American consular service).Winnipeggers fully understood. We're accustomed to this -- a collective cross we must bear - along with consecutive weeks of 30 below temperatures in winter, (compensated-for in summer by a deserved reputation as `mosquito capitol' of North America).And we've served as backdrop to some major Hollywood films lately. Before "Capote" for instance, "Shall We Dance" was almost entirely filmed here (including all interior scenes).  But then (as always) Winnipeggers searched in vain for recognition, beyond a line in the closing credits. (There was however a fleeting reference-or-two in the "Shall We Dance" DVD commentary track from director Peter Chelsom.)But there's joy in Mudville this day (March 21) --  for the just-released DVD version of "Capote" - with its warmly expressed appreciation for "Winterpeg."[This city's previous claim-to-fame on American TV screens? An episode of  "The Simpsons" -- spoofing "internet pharmacies" all of which seemed to be based in this city of 700,000 -- and where the "Highway 59, `Welcome" sign on Winnipeg's outskirts claimed to declare in defiance to rare visitors: "We were BORN here - What's YOUR excuse?"]----But hey -- it's the `look' of Winnipeg that made it the perfect setting for this great film! In the DVD's accompanying documentary, "Making Capote," producer Caroline Baron says that the city and the 'endless prairie' appearance of surrounding farmland and towns, was simply ideal."We were obviously looking," says Ms Baron, "for some place economical to shoot, but (which) also had that look of Kansas in the late 50s and early 60s . . . AND that also could double for New York City and Brooklyn at that time - a tall order for (any one) city - and amazingly Winnipeg had that look!"The downtown (has) been preserved -- and the towns around it (are) preserved so well . . . we were able to shoot almost the entire film in-and-around Winnipeg."Director Bennett Miller, who shares the commentary track along with his Best Actor Oscar-winner Hoffman, enthused about the local actors and extras who made the most of their moment-of-fame:"We found some great faces! 90-percent of the people in this movie came from within a five-mile radius of downtown Winnipeg."We found an amazing local casting director Jim Heber who probably brought more than a thousand people to be considered as extras!  So every single face (you see) was `selected.' If you see a face in this movie -- they were chosen!"[Heber told a reporter for the Winnipeg Free Press newspaper, "It's very nice to be appreciated (in this way).  You know, when you're making a `masterpiece' of the American cinema . . .  you have to have `due diligence'."]On a separate commentary track (with his cinematographer Adam Kimmel) Director Bennett Miller expressed an appreciation bordering on awe -- for the way Winnipeggers stood in line for hours, in order to comprise the audience at a local theatre for a scene in which the film's Oscar winner Phil Hoffman reads passages of "In Cold Blood" to a (depicted) Manhattan audience."It's one of those shots," said Miller, "that makes me think back very affectionately towards Winnipeg and its people."----After speaking of his personal difficulties in `nailing' the part of Truman Capote during the first week of filming, ("That's me thinking, How the hell am I going to get through this movie?") Phil Hoffman endearingly points out the appearance of Winnipeg's gift to ballet - prima ballerina Evelyn Hart -- in a party scene:  "The one on the right (there) is a very famous choreographer," he says - before director Bennett Miller corrects him on Hart's profession: "(She's a) Ballerina," says Miller. "Allison Hart? Do I have it right? EVELYN Hart! From the Royal Winnipeg Ballet."Big smiles at that one but . . . there'll be no "price break" for us - except at Amazon.com. The "suggested retail price" in local stores is almost 37 (Canadian) dollars. Plus 14 per cent sales tax. Just so we KNOW we're not in Kansas anymore.Mark BlackburnWinnipeg
summary: Not in Kansas anymore (DVD version added features)
