reviewText: I remember reading In Cold Blood when I was a teenager but don't remember the details. I've always thought Capote was an interesting character and Philip Seymour Hoffman an above average actor. So I knew I was going to see this movie sooner or later.Hoffman didn't disappoint me and kept the movie interesting, but I wasn't as enthralled as I thought I would be. Perhaps it's a case of high expectations. I wasn't sure watching it if Capote did feel real compassion for Perry Smith the intelligent talented and dare I say sensitive murderer or if he was fascinated with him for personal reasons. One line that stayed with me was Capote saying "It's as if Perry and I grew up in the same house. And one day he went out the back door and I went out the front." At the end of writing his book he was drinking excessively and near a nervous breakdown (which he did have later). He didn't want to publish the book until the two killers were hung. They keep getting a stay of execution.I found Capote, or at least the film's version of him as an intriguing and complicated man. I'll probably look up some more about him because the movie did get me interested in Capote as a person.

reviewText: "Until one morning in mid-November of 1959, few Americans - in fact, few Kansans - had ever heard of Holcomb. Like the waters of a river, like the motorists on the highway, and like the yellow trains streaking down the Santa Fe tracks, drama, in the shape of exceptional happenings, had never stopped there." (from In Cold Blood)Truman Capote invented the "non-fiction novel" with words like those.  The small town in Kansas would gain national fame when two vagabond criminals murdered a Rockwellian family of four, blasting shotgun pellets into their faces at close range and splattering blood onto perfectly made beds and floors that seemed to be washed daily.  The film "Capote" tells of the writer's immediate fascination with the consequences of such an act on a conservative buttoned-down town and his eventual relationship with the killers who stole Kansas' innocence.Phillip Seymour Hoffman plays the enigmatic writer and the pursuit that would haunt the rest of his days.  Those unfamiliar with the writer will get a crash course in who he was, his homosexuality, his drinking, his odd presentation and speaking.  But more importantly, all viewers will see how the killings in Kansas and their consequences would virtually end his writing career, as "In Cold Blood" was the only book he published in the last two decades of his life.In the film, Capote connects with the killers, as he sees the world divided into two categories: those like the church-going, milk drinking, "yes ma'am" saying murder victims and the rest of the world, the outsiders.  He and the killers belong to the latter group, and only a fine line exists between them.  "It's as if we were bothers, and one day he went out the back door while I went out the front," Capote says of Perry Smith, the man who slit the throat of the family patriarch.  Just as Capote faced ridicule and judgment all his life because of his eccentricity, so did the killers.  Thus, a bond.His initial quest for a story leads him on a conflicting journey, as he is torn between his duties as a literary journalist and the love he develops for his new "brothers".  As his relationship with Smith deepens, Capote wishes to fully understand the murderer and include his humanity in the book, so that the world won't forever think of him as a monster.  But the more he tries to whitewash through understanding, the bloodier his friend's hands become.Capote does not want the men to die, and the film certainly has anti-death penalty aspirations.  But it does not develop them irresponsibly.  The killers are not romanticized (a la Monster) and the people who support that act are not sadistic fire-breathers (Dead Man Walking).  The death penalty is shown for what it is: a brutal act brought about by the actions of horrible people.Hollywood is in the middle of a Renaissance with biographies and "Capote" shows them all how less is more.  So many films try to reduce a person's life to a few hours, an impossible task.  "Capote" instead trusts the audience to grasp the totality of the man by focusing on the most important episode in his life.  Audiences will come away from this film knowing as much about the essence of Truman Capote as is learned about Howard Hughes, Ray Charles or Johnny Cash in recent films of their lives.  But unlike the other three, "Capote" does not suffer from a disjointed, meandering narrative.  The focus instead is on one event, and the result is a biopic against which all others should be measured.

reviewText: "Capote" focuses on the time period when the author was researching "In Cold Blood."  Truman Capote was already a renowned author in 1959; however, the book would change his career and alter how non-fiction was written and perceived.  Clearly, being involved with that book changed Capote's life personally as well.  The film commences with the murder of the Clutter family in the tiny town of Holcomb, Kansas.  The murder was particularly brutal and made news across the country, which is how Truman Capote stumbled across the story.  Capote travels to Kansas with his friend, Harper Lee, hoping to write a story for the New Yorker.  Obtaining information was slow-going at first, as he was competing with other media.  However, Capote and Lee used their charms to make friends with local officials.  Eventually, Capote would become friends with one of the murderers - Perry Smith - as well.The acting is absolutely stellar in "Capote": it's really an "actor's movie."  Philip Seymour Hoffman has been outstanding in many movies (The Talented Mr. Ripley, Magnolia, Happiness), but playing Truman Capote has finally established him as a star.  He nails the nasally whine of Capote but also captures a deeper essence; after a few minutes on screen, he becomes the author, without question.  Catherine Keener as Harper Lee, almost unrecognizable in a prim hairstyle and drab librarian-style clothing, is also terrific.  I hope this will lead to another Oscar nomination for her.  However, the real find here is Clifton Collins, Jr. as Perry Smith.  I've been a fan of his for years, especially his flamboyant work in "Traffic."  He's finally found a meaty role worthy of his talent.The final star of "Capote" is the screenplay; it's a literate movie for certain.  The witty script is filled with the kind of bon mots and clever quips Truman Capote himself so often made in television interviews.  The film recreates the 1960s literary scene in all its sexy vibrance.  However, for all its cleverness, the screenplay is not as impactful as one would hope.  "In Cold Blood" arguably is one of the best works of non-fiction ever, and the 1967 movie adaptation was brilliantly stark and mean.  Given the source material, I expected "Capote" to be a bit more affecting.  The conflicted relationship between Capote and Smith is interesting, but it's also strangely unmoving here.  Some viewers may prefer that a film that depicts morality in so many shades or gray remain a bit distant, but I wanted some catharsis.  Nevertheless, "Capote" is a very good movie with outstanding writing and acting.
summary: "I couldn't have done anything to save them."

reviewText: I strongly believe that this film will certainly garner an Oscar nomination for Philip Seymour Hoffman. His portrayal of Truman Capote is mesmerizing, and it's even more challenging and convincing than his other works including Magnolia, Owning Mahoney, and Love Liza. I really didn't expect this film to move me, but that one scene when Capote(Hoffman) broke down into massive tears was so touching that I was crying along with him. This film is not a conventional biopic, since it only captures one major part of Capote's life, primarily focusing on his quest to uncover the truth behind the senseless murder of a Kansas farm family in 1959 in order to write his most acclaimed book entitled In Cold Blood. It covers the period when Capote was first inspired to write about the story upon reading the newspaper article, to spending more than four years of research and finally publishing the book in 1966.Truman Capote is an eccentric, humorous, and flamboyant openly gay writer. Hoffman certainly mastered the feminine mannerism, the babyish voice, and all the tormented heart and soul the Capote to perfection. Capote at one point told Perry Smith(Clifton Collins Jr.), one of the convicted murderer, that they are like twin brothers, and that one went out at the back door and the other went out the front door. They are in some ways, two of a kind, because they share very similar childhood abused and abandoned experiences. They just happened to have made very different choices in life. Smith chose to rob the farm family thinking that there was $10000 in the house, but he and his partner in crime ended up killing four members of that poor family for $45. Of course, that was the most important part of Capote's research, that took a lot of relentless pursuit.Catherine Keener plays Capote's best friend Nelle Harper Lee, who would eventually become an internationally with the release her novel To Kill A Mockingbird. Her performance is subdued, but her role is limited in screentime and not that challenging. Chris Cooper who played Alvin Dewey, the lawyer who refused to help Capote. The role is also somewhat low-key for the Oscar-winning(Adaptation) actor. Bruce Greenwood is delightful as Capote's affectionate lover, though they didn't have any love scenes to work with. The most striking supporting performance came from Clifton Collins Jr. who had some heavy duty scenes opposite Hoffman. He might be heading to the Best Supporting Actor cateogory come next month.Even though I found Capote to be kind of slow-paced, especially the first half an hour, it gradually becomes more gripping and emotionally affecting.
summary: A Brilliant Character Actor At Work!
